questions.text: All of these are antigen presenting cells (APC’s) except _____
questions.solution:
T cell is not an antigen-presenting cell. The antigens are presented by antigen presenting cells to T-cell.

Examples of antigen presenting cells: 

  • Dendritic cells
  • Macrophage
  • B cells
  • Glial cells (brain)
  • Fibroblasts (skin)
  • Pancreatic beta-cell
  • Thymic epithelial cells
  • Vascular endothelial cells
  • Thyroid epithelial cells

Professional APCs exhibit 3 major activities when they encounter pathogens:

  1. They secrete proteins that attract and activate other immune cells.
  2. They internalise pathogens via phagocytosis, digest pathogenic proteins into peptides and then present these peptide antigens on their membrane surfaces with the help of MHC II molecules.
  3. They upregulate co-stimulatory molecules required for optimal activation of helper T cells.

Each variety of APC have a distinct role in immune response, depending on its location and its ability to react to pathogens.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for the past 2 days. Patient was diagnosed to have fungal corneal ulcer and was started on azoles. What would be the most common cause of fungal keratitis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer. The most common cause is Aspergillus

Salient features of a fungal corneal ulcer:

  • It is caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter.
  • Signs are more pronounced than symptoms.
  • The corneal ulcer appears dry.
  • Delicate feathery finger-like extensions are present.
  • A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation) may be present
  • Multiple, small satellite lesions may be present around the ulcer.
  • Usually, a big hypopyon is present.
  • Pigmented ulcer (brownish) may be caused by some dematiaceous species of fungi.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur..

Image: Fungal corneal ulcer, with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion

This is an AIIMS pattern MCQ.

Steroids are contraindicated in a fungal corneal ulcer. Steroids make the fungi facultative pathogens which are otherwise symbiotic saprophytes.

questions.text: All of the following cause grey white membrane over tonsil except
questions.solution:
Peritonsillar abscess (PTA), also known as quinsy, is an accumulation of pus due to an infection behind the tonsil.

Symptoms include fever, throat pain, trouble opening the mouth, and a change to the voice. Pain is usually worse on one side.

Complications may include blockage of the airway or aspiration pneumonitis.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Apthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is used in classifying states and union territories under National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India,2016 ?
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence(API) is used in classifying states/UTs in the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. 

The annual parasite Incidence is calculated as: (Cases in one year ×1000) / Population under surveillance.

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

Goals :

  • To eliminate malaria throughout the country
  • To maintain malaria free status in areas where disease transmission is already interrupted and prevent reintroduction of malaria

Objectives :

  • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases to be achieved in all 26 states/UTs that were under category 1 and 2 
  • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
  • By 2027, indigenous transmission of malaria to be interrupted.
  • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

 

 

Related Pearl: Malarial parameters

Malarial parameters:

Parameter Formula
Annual Parasite Incidence       Cases in one year        ×1000
Population under surveillance
Annual Blood Examination Rate Number of slides examined ×100
      Population
Slide positivity Rate Percentage of slides found positive irrespective of species
Slide Falciparum Rate Percentage of slides positive for P.falciparum

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Categories according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Definition  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥ 1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥ 1.   Same as category 2

questions.text: Progestrone is secreted by ____ and is the  dominant hormone in the ___ phase.
questions.solution:
Progestrone is secreted by corpus luteum and is the dominant hormone in the luteal phase.

In terms of ovarian function, the menstrual cycle may be divided into two phases approximately equal in length and separated by ovulation (Figure):

The follicular phase, during which a mature follicle and secondary oocyte develop; 
The luteal phase, beginning after ovulation and lasting until the death of the corpus luteum.

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint.

The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include:

Type of Joint  Examples 
Synovial joint

Costovertebral joint

Costotranverse joint

Interchondral joints

Sternocostal joints (except 1st sternocostal joint)
Primary cartilaginous joint or Synchondrosis Costochondral joint
Secondary cartilaginous or Symphyses joint Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints

 Note :  

  • Sternocostal joints: They are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.
    • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint (synarthrosis). 
    • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.
  • Interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.
Syndesmosis is a true fibrous joint connecting between bones.
  • Connected by interosseous ligament, e.g. tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis
  • Connected by a dense fibrous membrane, e.g. posterior region of sacroiliac joint
 

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Vertebral articulations

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 1 and 10: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8-10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: During autopsy of a female , over-inflation of the lungs is seen. It is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum.
Emphysema aquosum is seen in cases of wet drowning.

  • The oedema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position. 
  • In drowning this may be sufficient to mark the lateral surfaces of the lungs with the impression of the ribs, leaving visible and palpable grooves after removal of the organs from the thorax. This may be one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning to be gained at autopsy.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural haemorrhages that probably reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages, and have been described in 50–60% of drownings.
  • Dilation of right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand. This is also not a finding which can diagnose drowning.
  • Haemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Note - Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

Note: 

If the victim is unconscious at the time of drowning, mere flooding of the lungs with water, but without formation of columns of froth occurs. This is known as ' oedema aquosum'.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Dry drowning- In this type of drowning, water does not enter the lungs, but death results from immediate sustained laryngeal spasm due to inrush of water into the nasopharyngeal or larynx. Thick mucus, foam and froth may develop, producing a plug.

Option C: Secondary/Post-immersion/Near drowning- It refers to a submersion victim who is resuscitated and survives for 24 hours. The patient may or may not be conscious. These patients may develop hypoxemia resulting in brain damage, electrolyte disturbances, pulmonary edema, sepsis, myocardial anoxia, etc., Death may occur from half to several hours after resuscitation in about 10-20% of people. Those who survive suffer from serious neurological damage.

Option D: Immersion syndrome- (HYDROCUTION/SUBMERSION INHIBITION )- Death results from cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition as a result of

  • Cold water stimulating the nerve endings of the surface of the body.
  • Water striking the epigastrium.
  • Cold water entering ear drums, nasal passages, pharynx and the larynx which cause stimulation of the nerve endings of the mucosa.

questions.text: A 7 year old female child visits  a PHC along with her mother  who came to attend the NCD clinic . The physician advised to start prophylactic  iron and folic acid supplementation  for  the child as per  Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme. What is the dose of iron and folic acid given to the child?

choices.text: Weekly , 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid
Monthly, 60 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid
Monthly, 45 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid
Weekly, 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg of folic acid

questions.solution:
Under the  Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme,children of 5-9 years of age are prophylactically given 1 iron and folic acid tablet weekly, containing 45mg elemental iron and 400mcg folic acid.

 

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

A key intervention is to give IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of anemia, under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme.

Note: These values are specified for the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme (2018).

Age group Dose and regime
Children
(6-59 months of age)

Bi-weekly

1 mL iron and folic acid syrup.

Each mL iron and folic acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid.

Bottle (50 mL) to have an "auto-dispenser" and information leaflet, as per MoHFW guidelines in the mono-carton
Children
(5-9 years of age)

Weekly,

1 Iron and folic acid tablet.

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated, pink-colour.

School-going adolescent girls and Boys
(10-19 years of age)

Out-of-school adolescent girls
(10-19 years of age)

Weekly,

1 iron and folic acid tablet.

60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated, blue-colour.

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating)
(20-49 years)

(Under Mission Parivar Vikas)

Weekly,

1 iron and folic acid tablet.

60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, 

Sugar-coated and red-color.
Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers
(of 0-6 months child)

Daily,

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy) and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red-color

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

questions.text: The given image of Rectus sheath represents a section:

choices.text: Below a point midway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus
Between the umbilicus and arcuate line
Below a point midway between xiphisternum and pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The diagram above represents a transverse section through the rectus sheath below the arcuate line. The arcuate line is located midway between the umbilicus and pubic symphysis). 

The rectus sheath is a fibrous sheath which encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It is formed from the aponeuroses of all three lateral abdominal muscles: external oblique (EO), internal oblique (IO) and transversus abdominis (TA). Each aponeurosis is bilaminar (having 2 leaves). 

  • The anterior portion of this sheath extends the entire length of the muscle and fuses with periosteum and ligaments at sites of the muscle’s attachments.
  • The posterior part of the sheath is complete behind the upper two-thirds of the muscle but absent below the arcuate line. Below this level, rectus abdominis lies on the transversalis fascia and extraperitoneal connective tissue.

The composition of the rectus sheath is as follows

  • Rectus sheath above the arcuate line
    • Anterior layer is composed of both leaves of the aponeurosis of EO and the anterior leaf of the aponeurosis of IO.
    • Posterior layer is composed of the posterior leaf of the aponeurosis of IO and both leaves of the aponeurosis of TA.
  • Rectus sheath below the arcuate line
    • Anterior layer is formed by the aponeurosis of EO, IO, and TA.
    • Posterior layer is deficient and the rectus abdominis muscle lies directly on the fascia transversalis.  

Pyramidalis is a triangular muscle that lies in front of the lower part of the rectus abdominis within the rectus sheath.

questions.text: Which of the following is a category C bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Hanta virus is a category C bioterrorism agent. All the other options are category A agents.

Bioterrorism refers to the intentional release of a harmful agent by attackers to cause diseases or fatalities within the human population or impact food crops and livestock. The aim is to instil fear among civilians or influence governmental actions.

As per the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the agents associated with bioterrorism are grouped into three distinct categories, namely A, B and C. There is no designated Category D within this classification.

Category C bioterrorism agents encompass emerging pathogens, such as Nipah and Hantavirus. These agents possess characteristics that make them susceptible to potential engineering for widespread dissemination in the future. Factors contributing to this risk include their ready availability, elevated mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of both production and dissemination.

Hantaviruses, classified under Bunyaviridae, are rodent-borne viruses primarily transmitted through inhalation of the virus present in the dried excreta of rodents. It causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) or hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Cat B

Salmonella typhi

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is that of "Meniere's disease". It is also called as endolymphatic hydrops.

PATHOLOGY:
The main pathology in Ménière’s disease is distension of endolymphatic system due to increased volume of endolymph. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph is secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

CLINICAL FEATURES:

Accordingly, the typical history involves episodic attacks of true whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. 

EXAMINATION:

Otoscopy - No abnormality seen in tympanic membrane.

Nystagmus - Seen only during acute attack. The quick component of nystagmus is towards the unaffected ear.

Tuning fork test - Indicate sensorineural hearing loss. Rinne test is positive , Weber is lateralised to the better ear. Absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear.

INVESTIGATIONS:

i) Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): sensorineural hearing loss is present.  
ii) Speech audiometry: Discrimation score is usually 55 - 85% between the attacks but discrimination ability is much impaired during and immediately following the attacks.

iii) Special audiometry test :

  • Recruitment is positive.
  • SISI score is better than 70% in 2/3rds patients.
  • Tone decay test - decay of less than 20dB.

iv) Electrocochleography: It shows changes diagnostic of Ménière's disease. SP/ AP ratio is greater than 30%.

v) Caloric test: It shows reduced response on the affected side on 75% cases.

vi) Glycerol test: Glycerol is a dehydrating agent. When given orally, it reduces endolymph pressure.

DIAGNOSIS OF MENIERE'S DISEASE: 

 Committee on Hearing and Equilibrium of the American Academy of Otorhinolaryngology- Head and Neck Surgery (AAOHNS) classified the diagnosis of Ménière's disease as follows:

CERTAIN: Definite Ménière's disease confirmed by histopathology. 
DEFINITE: Two or more definitive spontaneous episodes of vertigo lasting 20 mins or longer.

                a) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on atleast one occasion.

                b) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the affected ear.

                c) All other causes excluded.

PROBABLE: 

                a) One definitive episode of vertigo.

                b) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on atleast one occasion.

                c) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the treated ear.

                d) Other causes excluded.

POSSIBLE:

                a) Episodic vertigo of Ménière's type without documented hearing loss ( vestibular variant) or

                b) Sensori neural hearing loss, fluctuating or fixed, with disequilibrium but without definitive episodes (cochlear                             variant).

                c) Other causes excluded.

TREATMENT: 

A)  GENERAL MEASURES:

  • Reassurrance
  • Cessation of smoking
  • Low salt diet
  • Avoid excessive intake of water
  • Avoid over- indulgence in tea/ coffee/ alcohol.
  • Avoid stress and bring a change in life-style
  • Avoid activities requiring good body balance

B) MANAGEMENT OF ACUTE ATTACK:

  • Reassurance
  • Bed rest
  • Vestibular sedatives - Promethazine theoclate , Prochlorperazine , Dimenhydrinate
  • Vasodilators - Inhalation of carbogen, Histamine drip, etc.,

C) MANAGEMENT OF CHRONIC PHASE:

  • Vestibular sedatives - Prochlorperazine
  • Vasodilators - Nicotinic acid, Betahistine,etc.,
  • Diuretics - Furosemide
  • Propantheline bromide 
  • Elimination of allergen
  • Hormones 
  • Intra tympanic gentamicin therapy ( Chemical labyrinthectomy )
  • Micro -wick made up of polyvinyl acetate.

D) SURGICAL TREATMENT:

1) Conservative procedures: 

  • Decompression of endolymphatic sac.
  • Endolymphatic shunt operation.
  • Sacculotomy ( Fick's operation).
  • Section of vestibular nerve.
  • Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth.

2) Destructive procedures:

  • Labyrinthectomy

3) Intermittent low- pressure pulse therapy ( Meniett device therapy )

OTHER OPTIONS:

BPPV is not associated with hearing loss.

Syncope is associated with loss of consciousness.

Labyrinthitis is not associated with episodic vertigo like in Meniere's disease and is often bilateral.

questions.text: A 34 year old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of acute onset chills, high grade  fever, headache and malaise . On examination the physician finds out a punched out ulcer covered with a black scab on his back. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition ?

choices.text: Adult mite feeds on vertebral host
Tetracycline is  the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with presence of Eschar is suggestive of Scrub typhus and tetracycline is the drug of choice .

 Eschar-Punched out ulcer which is covered with a blackened scab. It indicates the location of the mite bite and it is the  characteristic feature of scrub typhus. 

Scrub typhus

  • Most wide spread Rickettsial disease
  • Mite is a vector
  • Vector – Trombiculid Mite
  • Causative agent – Rickettsia tsutsugamushi
  • Incubation period – 10–12days
  • Typical clinical feature – Eschar
  • Weil felix reaction – is strongly positive with Proteus strain OXK
  • Treatment - Tetracycline

In Scrub typhus both adult and nymphal stage of mite are free living in nature, hence they do not feed on vertebral host. The larval stage(chigger) feeds on the vertebrate host and pick up the rickettsiae. Rodents are the mammalian reservoir for scrub typhus.

questions.text: A newborn baby of an unvaccinated mother has hazy cornea, a heart murmur, and sensory neural hearing loss. The most common type of cataract seen in this patient's condition is ______?
questions.solution:
The conditioned mentioned above is the triad of congenital rubella syndrome

Cataract in congenital rubella is embryonal nuclear cataract where the central nucleus remains opaque/ pearly white nuclear cataract, which is progressive.

Ocular effects of rubella:

  • Microphthalmia
  • Rubella keratitis
  • Angle-closure glaucoma
  • Nuclear pearly cataract
  • Salt and pepper fundus (most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine.The given histology image shows the presence of membranous nephropathy. Which of the following statements are false regarding it?
questions.solution:
Membranous nephropathy is characterised by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the deposition of IgG and C3 along the sub- epithelial side of the basement membrane.
The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (intense pink color)

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.In majority of the cases(85%), it is truly idiopathic, while in 15% cases, it is secondary to an underlying condition such as,

  1. Drugs- Penicillamine, Captopril, NSAIDS
  2. Underlying malignant tumours- lung & colon cancers, melanoma,etc., 
  3. SLE 
  4. Infections- HBV, HCV, Syphilis
  5. Auto-immune disorders- Thyroiditis

Primary membranous nephropathy is an auto-immune disease caused by antibodies to a renal auto antigen. In secondary membranous nephropathy, the inciting antigens can be identified in the immune complexes. The antigens may be exogenous or endogenous.

  • Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes 

This disease usually have a variable course, most patients have

     - Insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome
     - Non- nephrotic proteinuria

     - Hematuria

     - Mild hypertension,etc.,

Because of the variable course, it is difficult to evaluate the effectiveness of corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive therapy.

Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops.

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s  is true about the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: A  mentally ill patient cannot make any decision on their  treatment
The patient is criminally responsible for attempting suicide
The mentally ill  can make decisions on how they want to be treated
Both a  and b are true

questions.solution:
The mentally ill can decide how they want to be treated by their healthcare professional as per the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

The Mental Healthcare Act of 2017


The act aims to reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support of those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and to protect the rights of those with mental illnesses. It also encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country by setting up more mental health establishments.

The provisions under the act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directive: The mentally ill can decide how they want to be treated by their healthcare professional.
  • Procedure for admission, treatment, and discharge of mentally ill.
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anaesthesia is used.

The Act also has clear instructions for the Central and State Mental Health Authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.     

 

World Mental health day is observed annually on 10th October. Mental health must be an integral part of the Universal Health Coverage. Nobody should be denied access to mental health care. It is therefore of great significance that the theme for World Mental Health Day 2020 will be: "Mental Health for All"

questions.text: As smoking is a known risk factor for lung cancer , a researcher wants to conduct a study to determine whether alcohol consumption is a risk factor for lung cancer. Which of the following sampling methods is ideal for his study ?
questions.solution:
Stratified random sampling is the ideal sampling method for this study.

In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

In this case the researcher wants to conduct a research study to determine if alcohol consumption is a risk factor for lung cancer. As smoking is mentioned as a known risk factor for lung cancer he must first stratify the population into smokers and non-smokers and also smoking is associated with alcohol consumption. 

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • A random is defined by the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.
  • For example, picking 4 random cards from a bag full of cards.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • For example, if a researcher wants to do a study on 100 doctors working in hospitals in Bangalore, he would select a cluster of 10 hospitals (clusters) and then take 10 doctors from each hospital as part his sample.
  • This is usually done when large scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 10th person to be admitted to the hospital can be selected or every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: Serum auto-antibodies associated with drug induced lupus react with ________
questions.solution:
Anti-histone antibody, an antibody against histone associated with DNA in chromatin, is seen particularly in cases of drug- induced lupus than SLE.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in which injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

An SLE like syndrome may develop in patients receiving variety of drugs, including 

  • Hydralazine
  • Procainamide
  • Isoniazid
  • Chlorpromazine
  • D- Penicillamine
  • Anti- TNF Therapy

Many of these drugs are associated with the development of ANAs, but most patients do not have symptoms of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are present in 75% of cases of DIL.


The mainstay of treatment is recognition and discontinuation of the offending drug. Development of positive ANA alone after receiving a drug shall not be a reason for discontinuation of the drug, although these patients shall be closely monitored for the development of DIL. Symptoms of DIL usually resolve within a few weeks of discontinuation of the medication, although rarely, they may last several months. NSAIDs or low dose corticosteroids may be considered for milder manifestations, with high dose corticosteroids reserved for more serious manifestations such as symptomatic pericardial effusion. 

Other options:

  • Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are specific for primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self IgG found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is also found in other collagen tissue disorders.
  • Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with the calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia (CREST) syndrome.

More common in black & ancients than white

More common in blacks and whites

questions.text: A motorcyclist has met with an accident and had died on the spot. During autopsy, his skull showed the following fracture. Name the fracture.
questions.solution:
The image shows Hinge fracture/ motorcyclists fracture.

Here base of skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge.

A heavy impact on the side or top of the head often leads to the vault fracture running into the base of the skull, usually across the floor of the middle cranial fossa along the anterior margin of the petrous temporal bone.

The mechanism of fracture is severe hyper extension injury of the neck. Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, such as pontomedullary tears.

Related Pearl: Most common injuries in a Road Traffic Accident

 Scenario Injury
Unrestrained driver

Face and head injury

Cervical spine injury

Steering wheel impact - Thoracic injuries

Pelvic fracture

Leg fracture
Seatbealt injury

Bruising

Rupture of mesentery or small intestine

Abdominal aorta injury

Lumbar spine fracture
Airbag injury

Facial bruising

Amputation of fingers

Fractures arms

Cervical spine and head injury
Front-seat passenger 

The pattern of injuries is similar to that of the driver, but this position in the car is even more dangerous.

Though there is no steering wheel to impact into the chest, its absence also denies the slight protection offered to the driver in reducing the collision with the windscreen, perhaps by giving him something to brace against.

Abdominal injuries more frequently in drivers than passengers.
Rear-seat passenger Safety for front-seat occupants has improved over the last decade, to the point where, for occupants over 15 years of age, the front seat is safer than the rear seat.
Motorcyclist 

Basal skull fracture - Hinge fracture

Brush abrasions

Tail gating
Pedestrian

Lower limb injuries

Head injuries

 

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding vertebral column curvature is true?

choices.text: The pelvic curve is concave posteroinferiorly
Cervical curve appears when the infant starts supporting its head.
Thoracic curve develops when the infant starts walking.

questions.solution:
Cervical curve appears when the infant starts supporting its head.

ALL other options are false.

During embryonic life, the body appears flexed and has 2 primary spinal curvatures. These are the thoracic and the pelvic curves, which are convex dorsally (kyphosis).

After birth, functional muscle development leads to the early appearance of secondary spinal curvatures. These are the cervical and the lumbar curves, both of which are convex forwards (lordosis).

  • The secondary cervical curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for the head extension.
  • The secondary lumbar curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for sitting upright and walking.  

Normal adult curvatures of the vertebral column are as follows: 

  • The cervical curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
  • The thoracic curve is kyphosis (convex dorsally)
  • The lumbar curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
  • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum?
questions.solution:
Ligament of berry, also called suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Other options:

Option A: Pretrachial fascia encloses the thyroid gland and is attached to the larynx. This attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

Option C: Thyrohyoid membrane is a fibro-elastic ligament, which arises from the superior margin of the thyroid cartilage, and gets attached to the hyoid bone. It facilitates the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.

Option D: 

The upward extension of the thyroid swelling is prevented by the attachment of sternothyroid to the thyroid cartilage.

The thyroid gland can only enlarge anteriorly, posteriorly, laterally, and inferiorly. The superior extension of thyroid swelling is limited by two muscles namely: sternothyroid and sternohyoid.

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever and rash as shown in the image . Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Maximum spread occurs one  week before the onset of rash

questions.solution:
The image depicts the rash of chickenpox which is caused by Varicella zoster virus - Human Herpes virus-3.

Characteristics of rash of chicken pox

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dew drop on Rose-petal appearance

Pleomorphism - It is characteristic feature of the rash in chickenpox, that is, all stages of the rash (papules, vesicles and crusts) may be seen simultaneously at one time, in the same area.

The communicable period of chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.

Secondary attack rate of chicken pox is very high, at about 90%.

The scab is not infective.The virus tends to die out before the pustular stage . The patient ceases to be infectious once the lesions have crusted

Related Pearl: Period of communicability of important diseases

  • Chicken pox – 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after appearance of rash
  • Tetanus – not communicable
  • Hepatitis B – One month before the appearance of Jaundice till the disappearance of HbsAg
  • Measles- 4 days before to 4 days after appearance of rash
  • Rubella – 7 days before to 7 days after the rash
  • Mumps -4-6 days before to 7 days after symptoms onset
  • Pertussis- 7 days before to 3 weeks after the onset of paroxysms
  • Diphtheria – Up to 4 weeks after disease onset
  • Meningococcal meningitis – till Meningococci are absent from nasal/throat swabs
  • Influenza – 1 to 2 days before and 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms

questions.text: Identify the toxin produced from the leaves of this plant.
questions.solution:
The given plant is Erythroxylum coca.

Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the leaves of cultivated varieties of coca.

ACTION:

 It desensitises the terminal nerves and causes vasoconstriction at the site of application. It is a powerful CNS stimulant for a shorter time , followed by depression. 

 It has sympathomimetic properties.

 The euphoric effects depends upon the release of dopamine, serotonin and neurotransmitters. 

SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS:

1) Stage of Excitement - there is bitter taste , dryness in mouth, dysphagia, feeling of well-being & loss of depression and fatigue. The patient becomes talkative. The pulse is rapid , pupil dilated, pallor of the skin, cyanosis, sweating and the temperature is raised. It produces hypertension. There may be tremors or even convulsions. There is often a feeling of tingling & numbness in the hands and feet.

2) Stage of depression - Within an hour or less, respiration becomes feeble, profuse perspiration, collapse, convulsions and death occurs. Death is due to respiratory/ cardiac failure or vascular collapse.

  • Large doses or a binge may result in anxiety and panic leading to paranoia.
  • Cocaine + Heroine is called SPEED BALL.

Fatal dose : One gm orally.

Fatal period: Few minutes to few hours

Complications: Cerebro-vascular accidents, sub-arachnoid or intra-cerebral hemorrhage, myocardial infarction, skin necrosis, aortic dissection and pulmonary infarcts.

TREATMENT: 

  1. Airway and circulatory stabilisation.
  2. If taken by mouth, perform gastric lavage.
  3. If applied to the nose or throat, wash out the mucous membranes with water.
  4. If injected, apply a ligature above the part.
  5. Convulsions should be controlled with chloroform or short - acting barbiturates.
  6. Amyl nitrite is the antidote and is given by inhalation.
  7. Thiamine 100 mg IV.
  8. Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg I.V.
  9. Symptomatic management.

 

Extra- edge: 

COCAINE HABIT:

Also called cocainism / cocainophagia / cocainomania. Chronic abusers can tolerate even 10 gm a day.

MAGNAN SYNDROME:

Also called cocaine bugs. There is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to itching sensation ( formication, tactile hallucination ) with resultant excoriation , leading to irregular scratches and ulcers.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study in a  village in India. He finds out that  the crude birth rate in that area  is 20 per 1000 people. If the total population of the village is 3000 what is the number of pregnant females ?
questions.solution:
The number of pregnant females is 66.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 20 per 1000 people i.e 20 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 20 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 3000, the total no of pregnant females = 20 x 3000/1000 = 60

Step 3: We should also consider the pregnancy wastage i.e 10% of total live births =10 x 60/100=6 (since some pregnancies may not result in live birth i.e abortions and stillbirths, a correction factor of 10% is to be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies)

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live birth + pregnancy wastage = 60+6=66

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

  • Crude birth rate
    • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory.
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year.
    • Birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/Estimated mid-year population
    • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population
  • General Fertility Rate
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15 - 49 years) in a given year.
    • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age in the same area in the same year.
    • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
    • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth
  • Age-specific fertility rates
    • It is the number of live births in a year to 1000 women in any specified age group.
    • It is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.
    • ASFR = Number of live births in a particular age group x 1000/Mid-year female population of the same age group.
  • Total Fertility Rate
    • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
    • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
    • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.
  • Gross Reproductive Rate
    • It is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.
  • Net Reproduction Rate
    • It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
    • NRR is a demographic indicator.
    • NRR of 1 is equivalent of approximately the 2 child norm.
    • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false  about the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme?

choices.text: A TB patient who has taken ATT for  < 1 month is considered as a new case
Treatment is only given to smear positive cases
Direct Observed Treatment Short course strategy is applied

questions.solution:
ATT can be started in even if smear is negative and if the patient is a clinically diagnosed case of TB.

Case definition: 

Microbiologically confirmed TB

A patient is considered as microbiologically confirmed TB case if the biological specimen is positive for acid-fast bacilli, or positive for mycobacterium TB on culture, or positive for TB through Quality Assured Rapid Diagnostic molecular test.

Clinically diagnosed TB case

It refers to a presumptive TB patient who is not microbiologically confirmed, but has been diagnosed with active TB by a clinician on the basis of X-ray abnormalities, histopathology or clinical signs 

DOTS stands for Direct Observed Treatment Short-course and is given by peripheral and voluntary health workers.

Recent updates in RNTCP:

  • Active case finding for TB has been started.
  • Follow up: 
    • On treatment: monthly follow up. 
    • After treatment: Follow up at 6, 12, 18 and 24 months.
    • A sputum smear examination must be done at the end of intensive phase (IP) and at the end of treatment.

Recent update: In 2020 RNTCP has been renamed to National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown / undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug ResistantTB regimen

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The cross-section shown in the image is at the level of T3-T4.

The cross-section shows a large vascular opening of the arch of aorta, along with three small openings corresponding to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery. This suggests that the section was taken at the level between T3 and T4.

Other options:

  • In cross-sections at the levels of T1-T2 and T2-T3, only the small vascular openings of the branches arising from the arch of aorta would be visible.
  • In cross-section at the level of T4-T5, where, the arch of aorta begins and ends, bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk is visible.

questions.text: A term male child was brought to the forensic department for post-mortem. The baby was thought to be stillbirth. While doing the hydrostatic test, the lungs float in the water. An unrespired lung may float due to:
questions.solution:
An unrespired lung (still birth) may float due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as Floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test. It is based on the principle that the specific gravity of the unrespired lungs varies from 1.04 to 1.05 and that of  the respired lungs is 0.94, because of the increase in volume due to inhalation of air.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth.

If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is a stillborn.

A respired lung (live birth) may sink in water in the following conditions :

  • Lung edema
  • Lung collapse
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis

Hydrostatic test is not necessary when:

  1. The fetus is born before 180 days of gestation.
  2. The fetus is a monster and thereby incapable of leading a separate existence.
  3. The fetus shows signs of intra-uterine macerations.
  4. The umbilical cord has separated and the umbilicus has cicatrised.
  5. The stomach contains milk showing active digestive system. 

Other tests to determine if respiration has taken place or not are : 

  • Fodere’s test :  Weight of lungs before respiration : 30-40g, after respiration : 60-66g
  • Ploucquet’s test : Weight of lungs Before respiration : 1/70 of body weight, after respiration : 1/35 of body weight 
  • Wredin’s test : Assesses the changes in middle ear. The gelatinous substance in the middle ear is replaced by air if respiration has taken place.

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a foetus after respiration.

Principle : Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Foetus is macerated or mummified.
  • Foetus is born before 180 days of gestation.
  • Stomach contains milk.
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed.

questions.text: A 6-month old -baby is brought with a history of bilaterally hazy corneas since birth. Corneas are thick, but the diameters are normal. Facies was normal. Which one of the following regarding this condition is not true?

choices.text: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is likely to be normal
Corneal thickness that is two to three times the normal levels
Descemet’s membrane may be thickened due to an abnormal endothelium.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of bilateral congenital cloudy cornea associated with normal diameters and thick cornea is most likely suggestive of congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED). Clinical presentation is usually watering and photophobia

In CHED, Descemet’s membrane is abnormally thickened.

Key features of this condition are a corneal thickness that is two to three times the normal, normal intraocular pressure (IOP), and normal corneal diameter. Associated features are corneal pannus, nystagmus, and esotropia.

The combination of congenital endothelial dystrophy and progressive neural deafness is known as Harboyan syndrome. This disorder must be distinguished from another autosomal recessive disorder, congenital endothelial dystrophy, in which deafness does not occur.

Related Pearl: Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea

Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea (STUMPED)

S - Sclerocornea

T - Tears in the Descemet membrane secondary to birth trauma or congenital glaucoma

U - Ulcer

M - Mucopolysaccharidosis

P - Peters anomaly

E - Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy

D - Dermoid

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes with severe headache and difficulty in moving his right hand and leg. CT Angiogram showed a ruptured aneurysm in the Circle of Willis area. Which of the following drug is indicated to prevent neurological sequelae for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The drug indicated to prevent neurological sequelae for this patient is nimodipine.

It is a short-acting Dihyro Pyridine calcium channel blocker that penetrates the blood-brain barrier and has a high affinity for the cerebral blood vessels. It is believed to selectively relax cerebral vasculature and is approved for the prevention and treatment of neurological deficits due to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage or ruptured congenital intracranial aneurysms.

Nimodipine can significantly improve clinical outcomes, and it can reduce the occurrence of symptomatic cerebral vasospasm and delayed neurological function deficits. It also reduces mortality after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Korner’s septum is:
questions.solution:
• The persistant petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum.
  • Separating superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.
  • Korner’s septum is surgically important as it may cause difficulty in locating the antrum and the deeper cells, thereby leading to incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy.
  • Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man experiences severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. He was admitted to the emergency ward. ECG showed ST segment elevation in precordial leads. What is the most probable finding in relation to blood Lactate Dehydrogenase levels?
questions.solution:
Flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio  (LDH 1 > LDH 2)

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream.

Higher levels of LDH 1 than LDH 2 (flipped pattern) in the blood is suggestive of myocardial infarction.

LDH: A tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (Heart) and M isoform (Muscle)

  • LDH-1: Heart.
  • LDH-2: Blood.
  • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas.
  • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle.
  • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Identify the following cells in the peripheral blood smear and the condition in which they are found.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anemia of liver disease, which is characterized by only a few spicules of varying size that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions with acanthocytes:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Myelo dysplastic syndrome 
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • McLeod syndrome 
  • Choreo- acanthocytosis syndrome 

The clinical significance of acanthocytes lies in their vulnerability to get trapped in the spleen due to their structure and gets destroyed leading to anemia. When remodeled by spleen, the spikes of acanthocytes become more blunt and the cell itself becomes more spherocytic; they are called as 'spheroacanthocytes' or ' spur cells'

In the image given below, Echinocytes or Burr cells are seen, here the projections of the red cell membrane are smaller, regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations and much more uniform in shape and distribution.

Conditions with echinocytes:

  • Anemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artifact
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Early post transfusion of RBC
  • Myelo proliferation disorders
  • Disseminated malignancies
  • Vitamin E deficiency

Echinocytes are formed in hyperlipidemia due to liver function when the RBC cell surface receptors bind with the HDL cholesterol, inducing the change in shape.

questions.text: A 9-year old child presents chronic fatigue, growth retardation and epistaxis. On further evaluation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia and anemia was found. X-ray of the femur shows the following. Bone marrow biopsy showed cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features, X-ray showing Erlenmeyer flask deformity and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher’s disease (type I)

Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase).

It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.

It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly 
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
  • Bleeding tendencies
  • Bone pain
  • Osteoporosis, pathological fractures (Erlenmeyer flask deformity)
  • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3)

Treatment: Enzyme replacement therapy is available in the form of 

  • Human recombinant acid β-glucosidase (Imiglucerase)
  • Velaglucerase alfa
  • Taliglucerase alfa

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the early stages of glaucoma?

choices.text: Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber

questions.solution:
Laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc.

It is because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible up to the margin of the disc.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayonetting sign: Sharp angulation of vessel at margin of excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

 

 Image: Glaucomatous optic atrophy

questions.text: A cholera outbreak is reported in a village and the medical officer in charge assigns a team to chlorinate all the wells in the village. What is the minimum residual chlorine level to be maintained in a well in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Residual chlorine level in wells should be 1 mg/litre in this scenario.

Where there is a risk of cholera or an outbreak (cholera epidemic) has occurred the following chlorine residuals should be maintained: 

  • At all points in a piped supply: 0.5 mg/L
  • At standposts and wells: 1 mg/L
  • In tanker trucks, at filling: 2 mg/L

Note:

After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.

Minimum recommended free residual chlorine levels:

  • Cholera epidemic: 0.5 mg/L
  • Disaster/ Natural calamities: 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: How long does a male worker undergoing sterilization  get enhanced sickness benefit at full wages under the ESI act ?
questions.solution:
Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration of up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • The employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefits: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for up to 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, Myasthenia Gravis, Glaucoma, Coronary artery disease etc.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration of up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy.
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding

  • Defense 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage 
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- no cash benefit, full medical care is provided.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of daily wage for a duration of 91 days in one year 
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years for 34 specified diseases 
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
  • Maternity Benefit – Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy
  • Dependance Benefit– is at 90% daily wages, lifelong for the spouse and parents and till the age of 18 years for any dependant's child, however, the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter is married earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits – temporary disability – is as long as the person is disabled at 90% daily wages. Permanent disability – the lifetime pension 
  • Funeral Benefit – Rs.15,000/-
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs. 10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from workman compensation act 
  • Exemption from maternity benefit act 
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition (Page no: 877)

https://www.esic.nic.in/information-benefits.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male came to the hospital with a painful arm after he attempted to lift a 50 Kg dumbbell with his right hand. On examination, there is an abnormal bulge over his arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following tendons is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Long head of biceps is ruptured to produce popeye sign(not short head/long belly/distal tendon)

Popeye sign: On flexing the elbow there is an extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly as its unrestrained fibers contract.

Proximal tendon of biceps rupture can also produce popeye sign since proximal tendon of biceps refers to both long head and short head of biceps.

Proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function but produces a characteristic deformity - the Popeye sign.

Note:

The 4 most common areas of tendon rupture include Quadriceps, Achilles, and Rotator cuff (Most commonly, the supraspinatus) and biceps.

Biceps Brachii

Origin:

  • Short head arises from the apex of the coracoid process
  • Long head arises from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula

Insertion:

  • The two tendons end in a flattened tendon and attached to the radial tuberosity. 

Nerve supply:

  • Musculocutaneous Nerve (C5, C6)

questions.text: Given figure depicts the different waveforms of JVP. The waves 1 and 4 in the figure are___?
questions.solution:
The waves 1 and 4 in the figure are a wave & x descent, which corresponds to atrial contraction and atrial relaxation respectively.

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. A normal waveform has the following deflections.

  • a wave: corresponds to Atrial contraction
  • c wave: corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole
  • v wave: corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium
  • y descent: passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

The relation with ECG and different chamber pressures are :

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: All the following are recommendations of 	Kartar Singh committee except ________.

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

questions.solution:
The recommendation of One basic health worker per 10,000 population  was given by Chadah Committee of 1963.

All the other recommendations were given by the Kartar Singh Committee.

The Government of India formed a Committee in 1972 known as ''The Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning" under the Chairmanship of Kartar Singh and the report was submitted in 1973. Its recommendations were

  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker
