questions.text:
A woman arrived at the hospital with edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration. Which of the following is the most likely food adulterant used?

Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item purchased from a seller who has now been arrested for food adulteration is suggestive that Sanguinarine is the toxic compound responsible for this.

Sanguinarine causes Epidemic Dropsy.

  • Contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil.
  • Toxic compound: Sanguinarine

Mechanism of action : Sanguinarine interfers with the oxidation of pyruvic acid which in turn accumulates in the blood and causes symptoms.

Clinical presentation: The patient presents with sudden onset, non-inflammatory swelling of bilateral legs which is often associated with diarrhoea. Some patients can develop glaucoma. Dyspnea, cardiac failure and death can occur in later stages.

Tests to detect argemone oil:

  • Nitric acid test
  • Paper chromatography: most sensitive(can detect very low concentration of argemone oil)

Other options:

Option A: Aflatoxins are produced by certain fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, are the most potent hepatotoxins. These fungi can contaminate food grains such as groundnut, maize, parboiled rice, sorghum, wheat, and tapioca. It is mainly due to improper storage. It can be prevented by proper storage after drying. Moisture content should be kept below 10%. They do not cause the symptoms described in the question.

Option C: Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals and Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs is associated with the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus leading to neurolathyrism. 

Option D: Rapidly developing ascites and jaundice is associated with the consumption of millets contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia which contain a toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloid and produce symptoms of endemic ascites, that manifest as rapidly developing ascites and jaundice.

questions.text: All the following are indicators of mortality except ?
questions.solution:
Notification Rates is a morbidity indicator.

Other options :

Case fatality rate :

Case fatality rate is the number of deaths from a specific disease during a given time period divided by number of cases of the disease during the same time period, usually expressed as per 100. It measures the risk of persons dying from a particular disease within a specific time period.

Years of potential life lost (YPLL) :

Years of potential life lost is an estimate of average time a person would have lived if they had not died prematurely.  It measures the years of potential life lost ,when a person dies before his expected lifetime (before an arbitrary determined age, usually taken age 75 years). A 50 year old who dies in a car accident could  have lived theoretically to an average life expectancy of 75 years of age; thus 25 years of life are lost.

Life Expectancy :

Life expectancy  is defined as  "the age to which a person is expected to live in a particular population if the current age-specific mortality rates persist". Life expectancy at birth is  influenced by the infant mortality rate where that is high. Life expectancy at 1 year of age excludes the influence of infant mortality, and life expectancy at 5 years of age excludes the influence of child mortality.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Crude death rate = ( Number of deaths during the year/Mid year population ) x 1000

Age specific death rate = ( Number of deaths in specific age groups/Mid year population of that age group ) x 1000

Sex specific death rate = ( Number of deaths per year of that sex/Mid year population of that sex ) x 1000

Case fatality rate = ( Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to same disease ) x 100

Proportional mortality from a particular disease = ( Number of deaths from a specific disease in a year/ Total deaths from all causes in a year ) x 100

Under 5 mortality rate = ( Number of deaths under 5 yrs of age in a year/Total live birth in that year ) x 1000

Survival rate = ( Total number of patients alive after 5 yrs /Total number of patients diagnosed or treated ) x 100

questions.text: Name the structure that pass through the opening marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The anterior interosseous artery passes through the opening in the interosseous membrane.

The common interosseous artery is a short branch of the ulnar artery. It divides into the anterior and posterior interosseous arteries.
 
The anterior interosseous artery passes distally along the anterior aspect of the interosseous membrane and supplies muscles of the deep compartment of the forearm, radius, and ulna. It is accompanied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve. Perforating the interosseous membrane in the distal forearm proximal to pronator quadratus, the anterior interosseous artery terminates by joining the posterior interosseous artery.
 
The posterior interosseous artery passes dorsally and descends deep in the extensor compartement of forearm. The posterior interosseous artery accompanies the deep branch of the radial nerve (posterior interosseous nerve) on abductor pollicis longus. Distally, it anastomoses with the terminal part of the anterior interosseous artery and the dorsal carpal arch.
 
The posterior interosseous recurrent artery leaves the posterior interosseous artery near its origin and ascends between the lateral epicondyle and olecranon. It anastomoses with the middle collateral branch of the profunda brachii artery, posterior ulnar recurrent artery and ulnar collateral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Dose response curve shown in the image below:

choices.text: Drug A is more potent than Drug B
Drug C is more potent than Drug A

questions.solution:
In the above image, Drug A is the most potent drug

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is Drug A > Drug C > Drug B.

Drug B is a competitive antagonist (Option D)

In competitive antagonism, the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while Drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

questions.text: Which of the following is a substrate in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Lactate is a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

The following serve as substrates for gluconeogenesis:

  • Glucogenic amino acids, alanine being the major contributor (alanine is the source of pyruvate). Glucogenic amino acids are converted into pyruvate, oxaloacetate, succinyl CoA, and alpha-ketoglutarate to enter gluconeogenesis and Krebs cycle at various points.
  • Lactate (L)
  • Pyruvate (P)
  • Glycerol (G)
  • Propionate (ruminants)
    (Mnemonic: L > P > G)

Fumarate, Succinyl CoA and Acetyl CoA is not a substrate for gluconeogenesis. Instead, they enter Krebs cycle for oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.text: You are a healthcare worker in an area struck by a sudden onset disaster . Which of the following is not a part of immediate measures taken after a disaster?
questions.solution:
Vector control is done  during the rehabilitation or recovery phase and not immediately after a disaster.

Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood during resting conditions (dark blue line) and blood during exercise ( light blue line)?
questions.solution:
In the exercise, several factors shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right, which serves to deliver extra amounts of O2 to the exercising muscle.

These factors include increasing the amount of CO2 released from the muscle tissue, increased H+ concentration in the muscle capillary blood, and increased temperature resulting from heat generated by the exercising muscle.

The right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve allows more oxygen to be released to the muscle at a given Po2 in the blood.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

questions.text: A military soldier who was posted a week in Siachen glacier complains of headache, nausea, and breathlessness. Which of the following is used in patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide is used in the treatment of acute mountain sickness.

This patient has been posted in a place high from sea level and is more prone to develop Acute Mountain Sickness which is characterized by nausea, vomiting, headache and shortness of breath. 

Acetazolamide is available as an intravenous formulation. It is also indicated in the acute management of open-angle glaucoma for the rapid reduction of IOP.

Dexamathasone, Furosemide and Diltiazem are not used in treatment of acute mountain sickness.

questions.text: A child presents to you with Hydrargyrism. All of the following are likely to be found in this patient except?
questions.solution:
Corrosive bronchitis with fever occurs after acute exposure to vapours of elemental mercury.

Hydrargyrism means chronic mercury poisoning.

FEATURES OF CHRONIC MERCURY POISONING:

  • Tremor - classical and the most consistent manifestations of chronic mercury poisoning ; includes :
Tremor   Severity
Danbury tremors

Are fine muscle fasciculations punctuated every few minutes by coarse shaking or jerky movements, intentional type.

First in the hands →lips→tongue→arms and legs.
Hatter's shakes Severe, daily activities involving delicate movements like shaving, writing, holding a tumbler or spoon become grossly impaired.
Concussio mercurialis Most severe form, literally no activity is possible.
  • Erethism mercurialis - Shyness, memory loss and change in personality
  • Nephrotic syndrome- Membranous glomerular nephritis 
  • Acrodynia (pink disease) - Seen in small children and characterized by a generalized rash; edema and erythema of the palms, soles, and face. 

  • Mercuria lentis - brownish deposition of mercury through the cornea on the anterior lens capsule.

Mercury

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Inorganic - GI tract

Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Characteristic clinical findings

 

Mnemonic: MEATS

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis (diphtheria like)
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

Note: Absorption of elemental mercury by the GI tract is usually negligible. So, swallowing the mercury contained in a glass thermometer does not produce adverse effects unless the mucosa is damaged.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented to the clinic with a sudden onset of high fever with shaking chills and jaundice. Examination reveals mild splenomegaly. Hematological examination showed the following on peripheral blood smear with hemoglobin 7.0 g/dl; liver function test values were elevated: total bilirubin 10.9 mg/dl with direct bilirubin of 4.0 mg/dl and low levels of haptoglobin. Which of the following can be seen on van den Bergh reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hereditary Spherocytosis presenting with Hemolytic Anemia. Van den Bergh reaction gives Indirect positive due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Van den Bergh reaction is a colorimetric method to measure the serum bilirubin level. It is based on the formation of red azodipyrroles when diazotized sulfanilic acid reacts with bilirubin.

Clinical condition Reaction with reagent Interpretation
Normal serum No reaction Negative
High conjugated bilirubin
eg: Obstructive jaundice		 Reacts in the absence of methanol Direct positive
High unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hemolytic anemia		 Reacts in the presence of methanol to give total bilirubin Indirect positive
High conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hepatic jaundice		 Reacts strongly both with and without methanol Biphasic reaction

questions.text: A 67-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with complaints of weight loss, fatigue and poor appetite. Blood work and bone marrow examination revealed megaloblastic anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a purple polypoid mass lesion of 5mm diameter in the paracardiac region. Histopathologic examination of the gastric biopsy showed the deposition of amyloid materials in the mucosa. Which of the following stains is used to stain the amyloid material?
questions.solution:
The Congo red dye is used for staining amyloid bodies, which are abnormal, fibrous, extracellular proteinaceous deposits found in organs such as the liver, kidneys, and spleen. The dye forms nonpolar hydrogen bonds with amyloid.

The stain may be used on both gross specimens and microscopic sections; amyloid of all types stains pink red colour. If the stained section is viewed in polarised light, the amyloid characteristically shows apple-green birefringence due to cross β-pleated sheet configuration of amyloid fibrils.

Image: Histopathology of gastric amyloidosis. Deposition of amyloid seen on congo-red staining and apple-green birefringence in polarized light.

All the other three stains mentioned in the options are used to stain calcium.

Option B: Von Kossa method: It is a silver reduction method, where silver is substituted for calcium in calcium salts like calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate, leading to the formation of silver phosphate and silver carbonate, respectively. In the presence of light, the silver compounds undergo photochemical degeneration to silver, which turns to black colour. This method is useful when large amounts of phosphates and carbonates are present, as in the case of bone.

Option C: Alizarin red S: forms an orange-red lake with calcium at a pH of 4.2. It works best with small amounts of calcium such as in Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, which are pathognomonic feature of malakoplakia. This method is also used on DuPont Automatic Cyclical Analyser (ACA) to measure serum calcium photometrically.

Option D: Azan stain is used to distinguish osteoid from mineralized bone.

Related Pearl: Appearance of Amyloid

Methods Appearance

Congo red stain on ordinary light    Pink or red colour to tissue deposits 
Congo red stain on polarizing microscopy   Apple-green birefringence 
Fluorescent stains (thioflavin T and S)    Yellow colour under UV light 
Electron microscopy  Nonbranching fibrils of indefinite length and a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm. 
X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy  Characteristic cross β pleated sheet conformation 

H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin

questions.text: A 42 years old male patient is brought to the hospital, with C/O seizures. Neurocysticercosis is suspected. What is the best investigation for identifying dead calcified cyst?
questions.solution:
CT is the best method to detect dead calcified cyst. The cysticeral lesions appear as small hypodensities (ring -like) with a bright central spot.

Definitive diagnosis is done by biopsy of the lesion and microscopic examination of the biopsy to show the scolex.

MRI is useful in detection of non-calcified cysts and ventricular cysts.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection. It is caused by the larval stage of Taenia Solium ( cysticercus cellulosae) 
Seizures are associated with inflammation surrounding the cysticerci in the brain parenchyma. These seizures may be generalised, focal or Jacksonian. When the cysts are in the ventricles, they obstruct the CSF flow, thereby causing hydrocephalus. Signs of increased ICP such as,

  • Head ache 
  • Nausea 
  • Vomiting 
  • Dizziness 
  • Changes in vision 
  • Ataxia  
  • Confusion are often evident.

When the cysticerci develop in the base of the brain or in the sub-arachnoid space, they may cause 

  • Chronic meningitis  
  • Arachnoiditis 
  • Communicating hydrocephalus 
  • Stroke, etc.,

TREATMENT: 

Asymptomatic Neurocysticercosis requires no treatment. 
For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis ,

Praziquantel- 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20- 30 days (or)

Albendazole - 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.

Cortico steroids may be given along with the anti-parasitic drugs to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.

Anti- epileptics should be continued for 1-2 years to prevent recurrent seizures.

Operative intervention is needed for patients with hydrocephalus.

In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated ICP due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the main-stay of therapy.

In patients with ocular cysticercosis and spinal medullary lesions, anti-parasitic drugs can cause irreversible damage ,hence should be avoided. Surgery is the treatment of choice in such cases.

Note:

About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

 

The image given below is a MRI- Brain showing neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: Which stage of sleep is characterized by longer, visual and emotional dreams and the EEG  resembling a low amplitude , high frequency pattern like  saw tooth waves?
questions.solution:
REM stage also called paradoxical sleep is the stage in which vivid dreams occur and EEG resembles that of saw tooth waves.

The EEG pattern also varies with each stage of sleep.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 20 days. The stool examination shows the following organism. Which of the following statement is correct about the disease caused by it?

choices.text: Paramomycin is the drug of choice.
It is present in the large intestine.

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image showing the pear/tennis racket/heart/pyriform shaped trophozoite form is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia. Cyst is the infective form.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. After ingestion, the cyst lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum. 
Giardia passes its life cycle in one host.

Incubation period is usually about 2 weeks.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea, fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, belching, and flatulence. The stool contains excess mucus and fat but no blood.
  • Abnormal stool patterns may alternate with periods of constipation and normal bowel movements.
  • It is associated with iron deficiency and growth stunting.

Diagnosis:- The String test/Entero test is used. It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis.

               - Sero diagnosis : Commercially available ELISA kits detects Giardia - specific antigen ( GSA 65 ).

Treatment: Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents.

Giardia is also known as the grand old man of the intestine.

questions.text: A 38 year old married female comes to the family planning OPD for IUD insertion. Which of the following history given by the patient is not considered as significant before IUD insertion?
questions.solution:
History of cardiac disease is not a contraindication in IUD usage, whereas all the other options are absolute contraindications for IUD usage.

 

IUD Usage
Absolute contraindications Relative contraindications

suspected pregnancy,

PID,

vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology,

Carcinoma cervix/uterus/adnexa/other pelvic tumors,

previous ectopic pregnancy.

anemia,

menorrhagia,

history of PID since the last pregnancy,

purulent cervical discharge, distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids,

uterine malformations,

unmotivated person. 

IUD can be :

  • First generation IUD – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop.
  • Second generation IUD - medicated with metallic elements like Copper eg:  Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375
  • Third generation IUD – hormone containing IUD – progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20).

Mechanisms of action of IUDs include:

  • Cause cellular and biochemical changes in the uterus and endometrium.
  • Prevent sperm penetration due to change in mucus consistency.
  • Prevent implantation by making uterus hostile to it.

questions.text: In a DNA molecule, the concentration of the cytosine residues is 32%. What is the concentration of the thymine residues?
questions.solution:
The percentage of thymine residues in the DNA will be 18%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

Purines = Pyrimidines.

Sum of Purine = Sum of Pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that cytosine is 32%, therefore Guanine is also 32 %. Hence Guanine + cytosine = 64% 

Adenine + Thymine = 100 - 64 = 36 %

No of Thymine =No of Adenine, so the percentage of Thymine = 36/2 = 18%.

questions.text: A 50 year old man came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, dizziness and blurring of vision of sudden onset.  There were  no associated co-morbidities. On probing, history of ingestion of home- canned beans is present. Patient had developed descending flaccid paralysis on 2nd day. A diagnosis of botulism is made. Which category of bio-terrorism  does the causative agent belongs to?
questions.solution:
Botulism is caused by Clostridium Botulinum and it belongs to Category A of bio- terrorism agents.

The botulinum toxin is highly potent, with 1 gram capable of killing 1 million people if dispersed effectively.

The toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by preventing its vesicle fusion with the motor neuron membrane, resulting in flaccid paralysis. Transmission can occur via contaminated food, aerosolized toxin, or growth in wounds, with the latter two relevant for bioterrorism.

 Patients initially develop multiple cranial nerve palsies, followed by descending flaccid paralysis. Severe cases may involve complete muscular collapse, loss of gag reflex, and respiratory failure, requiring weeks to months of ventilator support.

The diagnosis is suspected based on clinical presentation and mouse bio-assay and immune-assay. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses. 

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

questions.text: Botulinum toxin acts on ____________?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin acts on SNARE (Soluble N-ethylmalimide Sensitive Factor(NSF) Attachment protein Receptor) SNARE proteins play a critical role in the fusion of the vesicle and the exocytosis of the neurotransmitter from the pre-synaptic membrane. Inhibition of these SNARE proteins inhibits the release of acetylcholine from synaptic terminals.

It is useful in spastic and neurological conditions associated with increased cholinergic activity like

  • Blepharospasm
  • Spastic cerebral palsy
  • Torticollis
  • Chronic resistant migraine

Option A - Hemicholinum acts on nerve terminals inhibits the uptake of choline.

Option C - Hexamethonium is one of the drugs that acts as a ganglion blocker.

Option D - Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of Zika virus has been shown in the picture. Which of the following is a feature of the Zika virus infection?
questions.solution:
Zika virus infection is associated with Guillain - Barre syndrome. In July 2015, Brazil first reported the association between Zika virus and Guillain - Barre syndrome.

Zika virus is a mosquito borne flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. The symptoms of the infection are similar to dengue and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain.

It is classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV):

  • Family: Flaviviridae
  • Genus: Flavivirus
  • Species: Zika virus

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

The symptoms of zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may lead to microcephaly or congenital zika syndrome. The complications of zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy and myelitis.

NCDC Delhi and National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

Zika virus disease is usually mild and requires only symptomatic management. The patients should get enough rest, drink plenty of water and treat fever and myalgia with analgesics. There is no vaccine available currently.

OTHER OPTIONS: 

Chorio retinitis - seen in congenital CMV infection.

Sensori Neural deafness - seen in Congenital Rubella syndrome.

Petechial rash - seen in Dengue fever.

questions.text: The peripheral blood smear picture of a patient with Acute Promyelocytic Leukaemia is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as “Faggot cells” (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a tumour of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML) belongs to FAB M3 class.

Numerous Auer rods which are azurophilic granules are present in bundles with individual progranulocytes. Primary granules are very prominent associated with very high incidence of DIC. They are myeloperoxidase (+); cytogenetic abnormality seen in APML is t(15;17)(q22;q12). These AML cells express CD13 & CD 33 antigens.

Other options:

  • The term flaming promyelocyte has been coined to describe cells that appear to be “breaking apart”, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix.
  • Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear “dusky” or “hazy” and are referred to as such.
  • Buttocks cells are cells having a notched appearance that are found in certain malignancies such as, 

                                               - Non Hodgkin's lymphoma

                                               - Sezary syndrome

                                               - Mycosis fungoides

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about section 45 of IEA ?

choices.text: Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available
Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases

questions.solution:
IEA Section 45 gives information regarding Expert witness. 

The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

An expert witness may give his opinion

(I) upon facts which are either admitted, or proved by himself or other witnesses at the trial,

(2) on matters of common knowledge, and

(3) on hypothetical questions (questions based on stated assumptions) based thereon.

Hypothetical questions may be asked to extract an opinion from the expert, after he assumes certain facts to be true, describing a specific situation, even though he may not have first-hand knowledge of the actual case.

A doctor's testimony that a certain thing is possible is no evidence at all. A doctor's testimony can only be considered evidence when he states that the conclusion he gives is based on "reasonable medical certainty" (more probable than not in a medical sense) that a fact is true or untrue.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

A doctor can be both a common and expert witness. When he describes the wounds on the body, he acts as a common witness. But when he says that the wounds were antemortem or post-mortem, or they were suicidal, homicidal, or accidental, or gives opinion regarding the cause of death, he acts as an expert witness.

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male had trauma to the right foot, following which he complained of difficulty in walking. Examination showed the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch. Injury to all of the following structures may cause the given condition except:
questions.solution:
Peroneus brevis muscle maintains the lateral longitudinal arch and not the medial arch.

The muscles, tendons, and aponeurosis that maintain the longitudinal arches of the foot are two types:

  • Slings: These structures help to maintain the arch by suspending the arch from the above.
  • Tie beams (bowstrings): These are present between the anterior and posterior pillars and helps maintain the arch by preventing the separation of the pillars.

Pes planus (flat foot)

  • Medial longitudinal arch is depressed or collapsed.
  • As a result, the forefoot is displaced laterally and everted.
  • The head of the talus is no longer supported, and the body weight forces it downward and medially between the calcaneum and the navicular bone.
  • When the deformity has existed for some time, the plantar, calcaneonavicular, and medial ligaments of the ankle joint become permanently stretched, and the bones change shape.
  • The muscles and tendons are also permanently stretched.
  • The causes of flat foot are both PHYSIOLOGICAL and PATHOLOGICAL.
Causes of pathological pes planus:

1. Tarsal coalition,

2. Disruption of the tendon of tibialis posterior,

3. Rupture of the spring ligament,

4. Tarsometatarsal arthritis 

5. Hindfoot (talocalcaneal or subtalar joint) degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

The windlass (or ‘Jack’s great toe’) test involves passively dorsiflexing the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint. This tightens the plantar aponeurosis.
Accentuation of the medial longitudinal arch Physiological pes planus
No accentuation  Pathological pes planus
This test can also be carried out by asking the individual to stand with both feet plantar flexed while viewing the hindfoot from behind.
In physiological flat feet, the calcaneus swings into a varus position; in pathological pes planus it does not.
 
Causes of Pes cavus (high arched foot):  Neurological disorder (e.g. Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease, tethered spinal cord, poliomyelitis)

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Features

Medial Longitudinal arch

Lateral longitudinal arch

Anterior pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior pillar

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main joint involved

Talo calcaneonavicular joint (TCN)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Superior articular surface of calcaneum at the leveled Subtalar joint

Extremities (piers)

Tuberosity of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsal anteriorly

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

Ligament/intersegmental ties

Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament)

Long and short plantar ligaments

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Peristalsis.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of intestine.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which causes relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of a bolus of food.

The stretch initiates a circular contraction behind the stimulus and an area of relaxation in front of it. The wave of contraction then moves in an oral-to-caudal direction. This propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates that vary from 2 to 25 cm/s.

Other options:

Segmentation and mixing helps in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below:

Migrating motor complex.

The below image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in aboral direction at the rate of 5cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Related Pearl: Types of gastrointestinal motility

questions.text: All are intrinsic members of larynx except_____
questions.solution:
CRICOTRACHEAL is an extrinsic membrane of larynx
Membranes of the larynx:

Extrinsic membranes connect laryngeal structures with surrounding structures outside the laryngeal framework. These are:

  • Cricotracheal
  • Thyrohyoid
  • Hyoepiglottic

Intrinsic membranes connect laryngeal structures with each other. It includes:

  • Cricovocal membrane
  • Quadrangular membrane
  • Cricothyroid
  • Thyroepiglottic ligaments

questions.text: A 5-year old child presented in a state of hypovolemic shock with failed access to the peripheral veins.  A venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein was done following which sensations over the medial side of the leg was lost. Which of the following nerves is involved in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein denotes injury to the saphenous nerve which is a branch of the posterior division of femoral nerve.

Saphenous nerve:

  • It is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery.
  • It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over patella.
  • It then descends along the medial border of tibia along with long saphenous vein and supplies the skin on the medial side of knee leg and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

Note:

  1. Saphenous nerve may be damaged in front of the medial malleolus during venesection of long saphenous vein.
  2. The nerve may also get entrapped as it leaves the adductor canal.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presented with personality changes, abnormal movements, jaundice and pruritus. Slit-lamp examination of the patient is given below which helped confirm diagnosis .  Which of the following is decreased in urine?
questions.solution:
Urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are decreased in patients with Wilson disease.

Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutation of the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13. The ATP7B gene, encodes a transmembrane copper-transporting ATPase, expressed on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

Deficiency in the ATP7B protein causes a decrease in copper excretion into the bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in the liver, brain, and eye.

questions.text: Which of the following requires  direct input of energy in the form of ATP?
questions.solution:
Primary active transport requires direct input of energy in the form of ATP.

When a carrier protein transports substances against their electrical and chemical gradients (uphill movement) it requires energy and this type of transport is called active transport.

In active transport the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence many carrier molecules are ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium potassium pump

b) Ca2+ -ATPase

c) H+-ATPase or proton pump d)      H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

Other options:

The diffusion of solvent molecules into a region in which there is a higher concentration of a solute to which the membrane is impermeable is called osmosis.

Passive transfer of only solvent occurs in Osmosis.

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

 

 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text: Which of the following is true about lipogenesis stimulated by Insulin?

choices.text: Decreases the transport of  glucose into the cells

questions.solution:
Insulin decreases intracellular cAMP level to stimulate lipogenesis.

Insulin stimulates lipogenesis by

  • Increasing acetyl-CoA carboxylase.
  • Increases the transport of glucose into the cell.
  • Activates pyruvate dehydrogenase in the adipose tissue (fatty acid synthesis and glycerol-3-phosphate for triacylglycerol synthesis via esterification of the newly formed fatty acids)
  • Decreasing the level of intracellular cAMP (this inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue, reducing the concentration of plasma-free fatty acids and, therefore, long-chain acyl-CoA, which are inhibitors of lipogenesis)

questions.text: A researcher wants to assess  the socio-economic status of a particular area. All the following  scales can be  used for classifying socio-economic status (SES) except?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand people’s attitudes from responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are Udai Pareek scale, Kuppuswamy scale, Kulshrestha scale Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale,  and the Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: A patient  presented with vertigo, nausea and vomiting. On examination, he was found to have left-sided deafness, left side facial paralysis, sensory loss in the left side of the face, and incoordination and dysmetria in left arm and leg. Nystagmus was present. Pain and temperature sensation of the right leg was lost. The lesion is most likely located at?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons.

Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

Medial pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the paramedian branch of the basilar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestation
    • CN VI: Diplopia(lateral rectus muscle paralysis - the affected eye looks downwards and inwards)
    • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestation
    • Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract: Paralysis of face, arm, and leg.
    • Medial lemniscus: loss of touch and proprioception from the body.

 Note:

In this clinical vignette, due to the absence of characteristic features specific to lateral medullary syndrome, like dysphagia and hoarseness of voice (involvement of 9th and 10th cranial nerves), the lesion is most likely to be located at lateral pons (lateral pontine syndrome) and not lateral medulla.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Clinical features

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery

C/L loss of conscious proprioception, C/L hemiplegia, I/L tongue paralysis.

Lateral Medullary syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body, I/L loss of pain/temperature on face, Ataxia, Nystagmus, Vertigo, Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis and loss of gag reflex.

Weber's syndrome

I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out, C/L hemiplegia, C/L paralysis of the lower face

questions.text: TESPAL is the procedure of choice for which clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• TESPAL is the procedure of choice for recurrent posterior epistaxis.
  • Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleed. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred method.
  • It is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind posterior end of middle turbinate.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury seen in electron microscope?

choices.text: Small amorphous densities in the mitochondria
Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane
Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER

questions.solution:
Vacuolar degeneration or hydropic change  is a feature seen on simple microscope, not on electron microscope.
All other options are seen in reversible cell injury on electron microscopy.

Reversible cell injury is characterised by functional and structural alterations in early stages of mild forms of injury, which are correctable if the damaging stimulus is removed.

Reversible cell injury:

  • Cellular swelling
    • When there is adenosine triphosphate (ATP) depletion, the sodium-potassium pump fails. Sodium and water accumulate within the cell, and this leads to cellular swelling.
  • Fatty change
    • Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism, e.g., liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells.
  • Light microscopy
    • Small clear vacuoles may be seen within the cytoplasm; these represent distended and pinched- off segments of the ER.This pattern of non lethal injury is sometimes called HYDROPIC CHANGE or VACUOLAR DEGENERATION.
    •  The cytoplasm of the injured cells appear red (eosinophilic) when stained with haematoxylin and eosin due to the loss of RNA, which binds the blue hematoxylin dye.
  • Ultrastructural findings:
    • Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities
    • Plasma membrane alterations such as blebbing, blunting and loss of microvilli.
    • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
    • Detachment of ribosomes
    • Nuclear changes: disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments.
    • Accumulation of myelin figures in the cytosol.

Note:

Mitochondria is the earliest organelle affected in cell injury. While small amorphous densities are seen in reversible injury in an electron microscope, larger amorphous densities are seenin irreversible injury.

Myelin figures are made up of phospholipids.

Hydropic change or swelling of the cell is the earliest change seen in reversible cell injury.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of fever and rash. The fever was first seen 5 days back and the rash started 2 days back on the face and has progressed to his trunk as shown in the image below. He is diagnosed with measles. The giant cells present in the lymphoid tissue of this patient is_________.
questions.solution:
Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleate giant cells, which are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients with measles.

Measles belong to the paramyxovirus family.

Measles can be divided into four phases:

1) The incubation phase

The incubation phase typically lasts 8 to 12 days after exposure to the virus and does not have any symptoms.

2) The prodromal (catarrhal) phase

The prodromal phase begins at the onset of the first symptoms, which begin gradually and include a fever, a cough, a runny nose, and red eyes. Usually, the fever is the first symptom noticed by parents. The fever rises steadily and may reach maximum temperatures of 103F to 104F.

The runny nose with a profuse watery discharge, nasal congestion, and sneezing becomes prominent. Typically, there is a pronounced cough, which is hoarse, dry, and hacking. Some children may complain of tightening in the chest. The red eyes are characterized by increased tearing, eye pain that may be severe, and sensitivity to light. Other symptoms that are frequently observed during the prodromal phase include fatigue, irritability, a decreased appetite, a headache, abdominal pain, and a dry mouth and throat. Koplik spots are the peculiar spots present on the buccal mucosa and are considered to be a diagnostic/pathognomic feature of measles/rubeola in the prodromal stage.

3) The rash phase

Approximately two to four days after the onset of the symptoms, the rash appears, marking the beginning of the rash phase. The symptoms of the prodromal phase worsen with the onset of the rash, but then begin to decrease in severity. The measles rash is a flat or slightly raised rash and is not itchy. It first appears as irregular spots on the upper forehead or behind the ears and on the neck. Within 24 hours, it progresses to the entire face, head, and neck. Over the next two to four days, the rash extends to the chest, back, and extremities (as seen in the image shown), including the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It remains most prominent on the face, especially on the cheeks.

4) The recovery phase

After four to five days, the rash begins to subside, marking the beginning of the recovery phase. Sometimes, a fine flaking of the skin is noted as the rash fades. About 10 to 14 days after developing the rash, the child is back to a normal level of activity.

The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of the rash. Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash more than covers the period of communicability.

Cytopathic effect of measles consist of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option B: Langhans cells - TB granuloma

Option C: Morula cells - Tryponosomiasis

Option D: Touton giant cells - Juvenile xanthogranuloma, Xanthoma disseminatum, dermatofibroma

questions.text: A child of 9 years of age is brought to the PHC by his father as he has not received the JE vaccine. All the other vaccinations have been received as per schedule. The father enquires the doctor regarding JE vaccination for his child. Which of the following statements is false about the scenario?

choices.text: The JE vaccine cannot be administered under routine immunization in a PHC after 2 years of age.
JE vaccine is given via subcutaneous route
Live attenuated vaccine is given under UIP
A second dose of  JE vaccine is given under UIP in the endemic districts

questions.solution:
The vaccine can be administered to the child as he is eligible to receive the JE vaccine through routine immunisation till 15 years of age.

JE vaccine is administered in the left upper arm subcutaneously.

Note: While administering the live attenuated JE vaccine it is not advisable to clean the injection site with a spirit swab because some of the live components of the vaccine are killed if they come in contact with spirit.

JENVAC is a new inactivated vero cell culture derived JE vaccine produced by Bharath Biotech International limited in India. It is a Kolar strain-derived vaccine. The recommended dose is 0.5ml which is given intramuscularly at left anterolateral aspect of midthigh, 4 weeks apart starting from 1 year of age. Although a booster dose is recommended at a later period, the appropriate time for booster dose administration is not clear.

JEEV is another inactivated vero cell culture derived vaccine from the SA-14-14-2 strain. The recommended dose is:     

  • 1-3 years: 2 doses of 0.25 ml on 0 and 28 days
  • >3years, adolescents, and adults: 2 doses of 0.5ml on 0 and 28 days
  • A booster dose of this vaccine is suggested to be given after 12 months of primary vaccination in non-endemic areas.  

The inactivated vaccines are currently under the recommendation of IAP. Under the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP), a live attenuated vaccine is given.

questions.text: A microbiologist used a petri dish to culture a pathogenic organism and wants to sterilize it . Which of the following method is used to sterilize glass wares like petri dish?

choices.text: Autoclaving at 121 degree Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes
Flash autoclaving at 134 degree Celsius for 3 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degree Celsius for 120 minutes or less

questions.solution:
Hot air oven at 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours is used to sterilize glasswares like petri dish.

Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven at temperatures of 160° Celsius for 2 hours ensures carbonization of organic material and destruction of microorganisms and spores.

  • This method can be used for metals, glassware, some heat-resistant and/or water-immiscible oils, powders and waxes.
  • One of the drawback of  sterilization with hot air is that it has no penetrating power, and hence not suitable for disinfection of bulky articles such as mattresses.
  • Because it employs very high temperatures it destroys plastic, rubber and other delicate substances.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy child, presented with the history of fever, bilateral neck swellings and loss of appetite. On examination, there was pallor, silvery gray hair, oculocutaneous albinism. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly were also noted. There was past history of recurrent infections.Subsequently, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin count of 8.6 g/dL, total WBC count of 22.1 × 10^3/uL, with lymphocytes showing single large round to oval purple intra cytoplasmic granules. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chediak–Higashi syndrome( CHS ) is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. This results in enlarged organelles and defective transport. Affected phagocytes produce giant granules , which forms the diagnostic hallmark. There are giant peroxidase positive inclusions in the cytoplasm of leukocytes. This may be the result of autophagocytic activity.

CLINICAL FEATURES:
CHS is characterised by,

  • Recurrent infections
  • Defects in blood clotting
  • Oculo-cutaneous albinism 
  • Photosensitivity
  • Nystagmus 
  • Neurological dysfunction such as ataxia

Affected children are susceptible to infection with gram- positive bacteria, gram - negative bacteria and fungi, with Staph aureus being the most common cause of it. These patients have prolonged bleeding time with normal platelet counts, owing to the deficiency of dense granules in platelets. They also have progressive neutropenia & abnormal NK cell function.

The most life-threatening complication is the development of accelerated phase characterised by 

  • Pancytopenia
  • High fever
  • Lympho histiocytic infiltration of liver, spleen and lymph nodes.

TREATMENT:

High dose ascorbic acid may improve the condition of the children in stable phase.

The only curative therapy to prevent accelerated phase is HEMATOPOIETIC STEM CELL TRANSPLANTATION.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B : Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is of 3 types and is due to a defect in integrins and FERMT3 gene mutation, leading to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia and recurrent infections without pus. 

Option C: Phenyl ketonuria presents with oculo-cutaneous albinism and neurological dysfunction, but recurrent infections are absent. There is no lymphadenopathy and organomegaly.

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase positive microbes.

questions.text: Which of the following types of infarction is seen in spleen?
questions.solution:
White infarcts occurs in spleen.

Infarcts are areas of ischemic necrosis most commonly caused by arterial occlusion ( typically due to thrombosis or embolization ); venous obstruction is a less common cause. Whether or not vascular occlusion causes tissue infarction is influenced by collateral blood supply, the rate at which an obstruction develops, intrinsic tissue susceptibility to ischemic injury and blood oxygenation.

In this case splenic infarction was probably due to a thromboembolic event secondary to atrial fibrillation.

  • White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

 

  • Red infarcts occur
  1. with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  2. in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  3. in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  4. in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  5. when flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)
  • Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize or when microbes seed necrotic tissue. In these cases, the infarct is converted into an abscess, with a correspondingly greater inflammatory response. The eventual sequence of organization, however, follows the pattern already described.

 

The below image shows a hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary red infarct

The above image shows a sharply demarcated white infarct in the spleen

questions.text: A house surgeon sustained a needlestick injury while disposing a needle used to sample the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the following statements is true regarding HIV post-exposure prophylaxis?

choices.text: It can be given upto 5 days after exposure
2 drug regimen is preferred over 3 drug regimen
Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir  is given for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three-drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg, Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO and NACO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine(3TC) + Dolutegravir (DTG)          Once daily          4 weeks

If the Preferred Regimen is not available or contraindicated, Tenofovir +Lamivudine+ Lopinavir/Ritonavir or Tenofovir +Lamivudine+Efavirenz can be used as an alternative.

The protocol followed is: Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28-day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with stoke and his visual field testing revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe as the image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A patient presented with c/o  acute diarrhoea and vomiting 2 days ago . The doctor on duty assessed that he has recovered from dehydration and ordered discontinuation of the IV fluids. The ward nurse by mistake administered 0.45% NaCl to this patient. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams represents the fluid shift in this patient?
questions.solution:
The Darrow Yannet diagram in the image 3 represents the fluid shift in case of hypotonic fluid administration as seen in this patient. 

This patient did not need IV fluids but was administered hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl). 

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Total Body Water (TBW) is divided into fluid compartments:

  • The Extracellular fluids (ECF), which includes Plasma and Interstitial fluids constitute approximately 1/3rd of the total body water.
  • Whereas, the Intracellular fluid composes the remaining two thirds.

 

Hypotonic saline leads to decreased osmolarity of the ECF. This causes shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until osmolarity of both the compartents become equal. The fluid influx leads to decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. The net result is the decreased osmolarity and increased volume of both the compartments.

Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both the compartments.

Other options:

Image 1- Normal ECF and ICF balance.

Image 2- The addition of isotonic saline to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Image 4- Addition of hypertonic saline to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis  is done in many countries to protect the home population.  What form of prevention is this?
questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis is an example of Prospective screening, which is a form of primary prevention.   

Prospective screening is done for the benefit of others, who have not gotten the disease. This is done so that the disease is controlled and not spread. Thus, it is a form of primary prevention. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection, and people are screened for their own benefits of early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. e.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contain a Rossman fold-associated NADH domain?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase does not contain a Rossman fold-associated NADH domain.

Rossmann fold is seen in the family of oxidoreductases that share a common N-terminal NAD(P)+ -binding domain.

Rossmann fold is seen in:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • D-glycerate dehydrogenase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • Formate dehydrogenase

questions.text: The heights of male students in class is  found to be normally distributed with a mean of 170 cm and a standard deviation of 5cm. From the given data, we can  infer that approximately 95% of the male students  will have their heights in between the range  of ______
questions.solution:
95% of the male students will have their heights between 160 cm and 180 cm

In this scenario, the mean height is 170 cm and the standard deviation is 5 cm.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.

Thus, we have to add and subtract 10 (two standard deviations = 5 x 2) from the mean to arrive at the limits within which 95% of the population would have their blood sugar, i.e.,

170 - 10 = 160 cm

170 + 10 = `180 cm

So, 95% of the male students will have their heights between 160 cm and 180 cm

Below is the graphical representation of the question. The question is asking to calculate the blue region in the graph.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores
    • Deviation score of an element in a distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • It is usually denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • The sum of all the deviation scores of elements in a distribution will be zero. 
  • Variance
    • Variance is used to measure how far a data is spread out.
    • Technically, variance of a distribution is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution.
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Variance is sometimes called mean square.
    • Thus variance is calculated by the following steps:
    • Finding the deviation score of each element in the distribution.
    • Squaring each of the deviation scores.
    • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores.
    • Population variance is symbolized as σ2 and is given by the formula:
    • Sample variance is denoted by symbol s2. This is the more commonly used in statistics than the population variance. In the formula for sample variance, the denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance).
  • Standard Deviation
    • By definition, the standard deviation is the square root of variance (σ2 or s2).
    • Thus, the standard deviation of a population denoted by just σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s. Sometimes, it is also denoted by SD.
    • The formula for standard deviation of a sample (usually <30) is:
    • In population standard deviation, the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • The standard deviation is useful, especially but not only in normal or approximately normal distributions, as the proportion of population within the given SD can be calculated.
    • A low SD would mean that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect of Furosemide?
questions.solution:
Furosemide causes metabolic alkalosis.

The adverse effects of furosemide (loop diuretics) are

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hyponatremia and hypokalemia (Option C)
  • Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia (Option B)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Increased LDL-C and decreased HDL-C
  • Glucose intolerance: hyperglycemia (Option A)
  • Ototoxicity

questions.text: A 45-year old woman with recurrent left middle ear infection (otitis media) complained of partial dryness of her mouth to her ENT surgeon. Taste sensation and hearing were normal. After a thorough clinical examination at the hospital, the doctor concluded that the infection must have spread to a component of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) that supplies the parotid gland. On which of the following walls of the middle ear is this nerve component located?
questions.solution:
The tympanic plexus is located on the promontry, which lies on the medial wall of the middle ear cavity.

 The middle ear cavity is innervated by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, which forms the tympanic plexus with the caroticotympanic nerves from the internal carotid plexus of the sympathetic fibres. The glossopharyngeal nerve, CN IX, is the ninth paired cranial nerve.

Embryologically, the glossopharyngeal nerve is associated with the derivatives of the third pharyngeal arch.

Sensory: Innervates the oropharynx, carotid body and sinus, posterior 1/3 of the tongue, middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube.

Special sensory: Provides taste sensation to the posterior 1/3 of the tongue.

Parasympathetic: Provides parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.

Motor: Innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle of the pharynx.

questions.text: A physician working in COVID 19 isolation ward should dispose his face shield in_________.
questions.solution:
The face shield used by a healthcare worker during COVID 19 pandemic is disposed in the red bin.

  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep seperate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
  • Records of COVID 19 waste are seperately maintained

General solid waste such as left over food, used water bottles, disposable food plates, discarded papers and carton boxes of medicine is to be handed over to municipal solid waste collector. Yellow colored bags should not be used for collecting general solid waste.

Waste from quarantine homes/camps or home-care facilities with COVID 19 patients are disposed as follows

The risk of transmission of  COVID 19 from sewage water of healthcare facilities is low and not established but still requires adequate disinfection and waste water treatment as per existing practices.
