questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of pleomorphic adenoma in the left parotid gland comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after a parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The area is also pruritic. Which of the following nerves are involved in this condition?

choices.text: Auriculotemporal nerve and chorda tympani nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and lingual nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and great auricular nerve
Auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve

questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome in which secretomotor nerve fibres to parotid gland by auriculotemporal nerve regenerate and form abnormal communications with great auricular nerve.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating/Auriculotemporal syndrome:

  • Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.
  • It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland.
  • During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the nerve supplying sweat glands (great auricular nerve).This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food
  • Clinical features:
    • Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.
  • Management:
    • Prevention: Sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed will minimize the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibers. 
  • Treatment:
    • Antiperspirants with aluminum chloride
    • Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area
    • Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative

questions.text: Beta 1-3 glucan assay test is used to diagnose __________.
questions.solution:
Beta 1-3 glucan assay test is used to diagnose Pneumocystis jiroveci.

Beta 1-3 glucan assay test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi except:

  • Cryptococci
  • Zygomycetes
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis

The clotting cascade of the horse shoe crab ( Limulus ) hemolymph is triggered by fungal cell wall β- (1,3)-D-glucan (BDG). This reaction has been exploited to quantify its concentration in blood and CSF. BDG levels of ≥ 80 pg/ml is positive.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is used to sterilise all of the following except__________.
questions.solution:
Cystoscope is sterilised by 2% gluteraldehyde.
Plasma sterilisation is used to sterilise heat sensitive articles, such as

  • Arthroscope
  • Urethroscope
  • Laryngoscope

MECHANISM:

Plasma is known as the fourth state of matter. A radio-frequency is applied into it to create an electro-magnetic field. Into this field, hydrogen peroxide vapours are introduced which generates a state of plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. These free radicals damage the micro-organisms by denaturation thus making the articles sterile.

Sterilization control is Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus.

questions.text: A known asthmatic with primary open-angle glaucoma who previously didn't respond to topical Prostaglandins comes to the clinic for review. His IOP remains elevated with his current therapy with topical Brimonidine and oral Acetazolamide. What is the most appropriate next step of management?
questions.solution:
Laser trabeculoplasty: In cases where intraocular pressure (IOP) is uncontrolled despite maximal tolerated medical therapy as in this pt.

Timolol is one of the first-line agents used in the treatment of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) but it is contraindicated for asthmatics (Option A)

First-line agents:

  • Topical beta-blockers such as timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol 
  • Selective alpha 2 adrenergic agonist brimonidine
  • Prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost

Adjunctive therapy: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors 

Historically, beta-blockers were the most common first-line agents used in the medical treatment of POAG. However, with an increase in our experience with newer agents, specifically the prostaglandin analogues that facilitate outflow, they were recognized as being more efficacious in lowering IOP and systemically safer than beta-blockers. As a result, now they are the first-line agents in glaucoma treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and is now having multiple episodes of vomiting.On examination , GCS was 10 ,he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated BP in this condition?
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for elevated BP in head injury patient is Cushing reflex.

As he has h/o head injury with fall in GCS and vomiting there might be associated intracranial bleed and thus the intracranial pressure will be elevated.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

 

Other options:

J Reflex

  • The juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors are C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels.
  • These are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung
  • Produces rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery)
  • Causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

questions.text: The World health organization (WHO) definition of blindness is ________.

choices.text: Corresponding visual field loss to less than 20° in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity of more than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 in the better eye
Corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye

questions.solution: WHO has recently revised its definition for blindness. As per the new definition, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.

questions.text: Crown Rump Length is 26 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.solution:
Gestational age of this fetus is 7-8 months.

Crown Rump Length + length of lower limb = Crown Heel Length

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in lunar months from its crown-heel length (in cm). According to the rule,

  • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/ first 5 months).
  • Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/ last 5 months).

Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 36 cms. Hence, gestational age = 7-8 months.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody against Receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-Β ligand (RANKL gene) indicated for osteoporosis is  _____
questions.solution:
Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANKL that is indicated in the treatment of osteoporosis.

It inhibits the binding of RANKL to RANK receptors on osteoclasts and thereby inhibiting the activation of osteoclast and also promotes their apoptosis.

Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody acting against sclerostin (sclerostin blocks osteoblast proliferation) (option A)

Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antagonist (option C)

Basiliximab is a chimeric mouse-human monoclonal antibody to the α chain of the IL-2 receptor of T cells (option D)

questions.text: What is the dose of epinephrine to be administered in case of anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

1:1000 dilution can be used for intramuscular, subcutaneous and inhalational (nebulization) route of administration. For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and used cautiously.

IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.solution:
Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane.

questions.text: Increased BMR is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in Cachexia.

Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the energy expenditure by the body when at rest measured about 12 hours after the last meal, and is dependant on the individual's weight, age, and gender.

Cachexia is seen in a number of chronic diseases. In this condition there is considerably more loss of body protein although protein synthesis is not affected. In cachexia, continuous release of cytokines in response to infections and cancer increases the catabolism of tissue protein by the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, thereby increasing energy expenditure. This leads to a considerable increase in the Basal Metabolic Rate.

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate

BMR is decreased in

Protein energy malnutrition

Hyperthyroidism

Hypothyroidism

Cold environment

Addison disease

Cushing’s syndrome

Starvation

Cachexia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about theophylline is correct _____

choices.text: Increase in dose is required in cardiopulmonary disease
Decreases the breakdown of cAMP in smooth muscles
Decrease in dose is required in smokers

questions.solution:
Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that decreases the breakdown of cAMP levels in smooth muscles resulting in bronchodilation. (option b)

A decrease in dose (not an increase in the dose) of theophylline is required in cardiopulmonary disease. This is because reduced clearance of theophylline is seen in liver disease, pneumonia, and heart failure. (option a)

In smokers, clearance of theophylline is increased due to the induction of CYP1A2 enzyme. So an increase in dose is required for smokers (option c)

questions.text: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma, and peripheral blood smear shows the following cells with characteristic nuclei as in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei. These are neoplastic T cells. Their presence in the blood points to Sezary syndrome.

Both mycosis fungoides and Sezary syndrome are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that home to the skin. But, in mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells, with the characteristic cerebriform appearance.

The condition is often preceded by eczema or dermatitis for several years, which is the PREMYCOTIC STAGE. This is followed by infiltration by CD4+ T- cells in the epidermis and dermis as a plaque, which is the PLAQUE STAGE, which is followed by the TUMOUR STAGE. Late disease progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumor cells are not seen in blood.

However, Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma; The disease spreads to viscera and to peripheral blood as a leukemia, characterised by SEZARY CELLS having cerebriform nuclei. It rarely goes into tumefaction.

Mycosis fungoides / Sezary syndrome are indolent Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. They have a median survival rate of 8-9 years.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes with features of Upper Respiratory tract Infection. The patient is a known epileptic and has been on phenytoin for the last 2 years; takes NSAIDs on and off for his body pain. He was prescribed Erythromycin and PPI.  Calcium absorption would be reduced for this patient because of the usage of:
questions.solution:
Phenytoin interferes with the absorption of calcium

Glucocorticoids and tetracyclines are other drugs that interferes with the absorption of calcium.

Glucocorticoids and phenytoin depress intestinal calcium transport and reduce absorption.

Tetracyclines form insoluble complexes with calcium and interfere with the absorption (Not Macrolides - option A).

NSAIDs and PPIs do not interfere with calcium absorption. (Option B and C)

Phytates, phosphates, and oxalates also form insoluble complexes with calcium and interfere with absorption.

questions.text: Benedict's test was performed with a sample and the results are as shown below. Which of the following compounds does the sample likely contain?
questions.solution:
Sucrose does not give a positive reaction to Benedict's test as it is a non reducing sugar.

Benedict’s test is a test for reducing sugars. It is answered by all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulphate: Provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate: Complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate: Provides an alkaline pH

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

Clinical correlate: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of glucose in urine.

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea about the amount of sugar present in urine. Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

Colour of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe intermittent pain in his right knee for the past 10 weeks, appearing and disappearing sporadically. The patient plays on a soccer team and his knee feels especially painful during practice.The discomfort has grown more regular in the last week and is now compounded by marked swelling around the knee. The x-Ray of the patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has osteosarcoma, the most common primary malignant tumour of the bone and accounts for approximately 20% of bone tumour. Osteosarcomas usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones of the extremities, and almost 50% occur about the knee (i.e., distal femur or proximal tibia).

The most common subtype arises in the metaphysis of long bones and is primary, intramedullary, osteoblastic, and high grade.

Osteosarcoma is a malignant tumor in which the cancerous cells produce osteoid matrix or mineralized bone

It occurs in all age groups but has a bimodal age distribution.

Radiography shows large destructive, mixed lytic and blastic mass with infiltrative margins, which breaks through the cortex and lifts the periosteum, resulting in reactive periosteal bone formation.

The triangular shadow between the cortex and raised ends of periosteum, known radiographically as Codman triangle, is characteristic but not diagnostic of osteosarcoma.

The formation of fine lace-like neoplastic bone by the tumor cells is diagnostic.

OTHER OPTIONS: 

  • Ewing's sarcoma - A malignant bone tumour characterised by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation. It is the second most common bone neoplasm in children and adolescents, accounting for 6%-10% of primary malignant bone tumors in this age-group. It usually arises in the diaphysis of the long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.

 

  • Osgood schlatter disease - is inflammation of the patellar ligament  at the tibial tuberosity ( apophysitis). It is characterized by a painful bump just below the knee that is worse with activity and better with rest. Episodes of pain can last a few weeks to months. One or both knees may be affected and flares may recur. Risk factors include overuse, especially sports which involve frequent running or jumping. Diagnosis is typically based on the symptoms. A plain x-Ray may be either normal or show fragmentation in the attachment area.

 

  • Aneurysmal bone cyst - ABC is characterised by multiloculated blood- filled spaces. All age groups are affected, but most cases present in adolescence. It develops most frequently in femur, tibia and vertebral body posterior elements. Radiographically, ABC is usually an expansile, well- circumscribed lytic lesion with well defined margins. Radiographically, they appear as circumscribed “soap bubbles” or “egg shells,” with thin sclerotic rims surrounding the lesion, and fluid levels indicative of blood within the cystic space.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female, with a history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension, comes to the emergency room with confusion. Patient is not oriented to place, person and time. BP is 200/120, Sr. Urea 74; Sr. Creatinine - 4.5. Which of the following drug can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Fenoldopam is indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. Blood pressure over 180/120 with end-organ damage is defined as hypertensive emergency.

It is a D1 agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and is a rapid-acting vasodilator.

Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency:

  • Nitroprusside
  • Nicardipine
  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Esmolol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Phentolamine
  • Fenoldopam

questions.text: A researcher wants to study the changes in the incidence of dengue fever in a particular area over the last 10 years . Which of the following is best suited for plotting this data ?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease  with passage of time in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following transporter is inhibited primarily by loop diuretics and is present in the ascending loop of Henle?
questions.solution:
Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle has Na+ - 2Cl- - K+ co transporter that co transports one Na+, one K+, and 2Cl– from the tubular lumen into the tubu­lar cells and is primarily inhibited by loop diuretics.

Mechanism:

  • Na+ is transported out of the cell into the interstitium by Na, K ATPase in the basolateral membrane of the cell.
  • Cl– exits in basolateral ClC–Kb Cl– channels. Barttin, a protein in the cell membrane, is essential for normal ClC–Kb function.
  • K+ moves from the cell to the interstitium and the tubular lumen by ROMK(renal outer medullary potassium channel) and other K+ channels.
  • This is an example of secondary active trans­port.

Loop diuretics inhibit Na+/ K+/ 2Cl- symport present primarily in thick ascending limb of loop of Henle. 

Na+/Cl- symport is inhibited by thiazide diuretics .

 

 

Clinical correlation:

Bartter syndrome is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene for any of four key proteins: the Na–K–2Cl co-transporter, the ROMK K+ channel, the ClC–Kb Cl– channel, or Barttin.

It is characterized by

  • Chronic Na+ loss in the urine, with resultant hypovolemia
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Alkalosis

questions.text: The following image depicts the hybridoma technique of producing monoclonal antibodies. Which of the following medium is used in this technique?
questions.solution:
HAT medium is used in Hybridoma technique. Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of monoclonal antibodies. This process starts by injecting a mouse with an antigen that provokes an immune response.

The antibody producing B-cells are then harvested from the mouse and, in turn, fused with immortal B cancer cells (myeloma cell) to produce a hybrid cell line called a hybridoma, which has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the longevity and reproductivity of the myeloma. 

Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma.

The following are the various steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  1. Mice are immunized with an antigen, after several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  2. When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously, then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  3. Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with cells derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes (myeloma) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  4. The hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT) medium allows only the fused cells to survive in culture. Myeloma cells lack hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) enzyme; hence, they cannot grow well in HAT medium.

questions.text: A victim of rape was examined by a registered  medical practitioner. Vaginal swab was taken to look for traces of semen. All of the following tests are used to identify seminal stain except:
questions.solution:
Teichmann test is used to identify blood stains.

Some tests used to identify seminal stains are:

Barberio's test: A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to spermatic fluid produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine citrate. Creatine phosphokinase test: Spermatozoa contains a high concentration of creatine phosphokinase, which is more than double, than found in any other body fluid. Normal seminal fluid contains 385 to 1400 units of CPK/ml. Levels over 400 are diagnostic of seminal stains. The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains of six months. 

Acid phosphatase test: The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations upto 36 hours after it's deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia.

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

Teichmann, Takayama and Kastlemeyer tests are used to detect blood stains.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Arterial supply of the organ marked in the image below is mainly by branches of:

choices.text: Right gastric, splenic and right renal  arteries
Common hepatic, gastroduodenal, and splenic artery
Coeliac trunk and superior mesenteric artrey

questions.solution:
The organ marked in the image is PANCREAS.

Arterial supply of the pancreas is mainly by branches of the coeliac trunk and superior mesenteric artery.

 
 
 

Arterial supply of the pancreas:

  • Head and uncinate process
    • Anterior and posterior superior pancreatoduodenal arteries [branches of gastroduodenal artery, which is a branch of the celiac trunk]
    • Anterior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries [branches of inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery, which is a branch of superior mesenteric artery]
  • Body and tail [Branches of the splenic artery, which is a branch of celiac trunk]
    • Dorsal pancreatic artery
    • Great pancreatic artery
    • Artery to the tail of the pancreas

Options A and C: While branches of coeliac trunk and splenic artery do supply pancreas, these options do not include superior mesenteric artery.

Option B: Right gastric and right renal arteries do not supply the pancreas.

Hence, Option D is the best answer as it includes gastroduodenal artery, splenic artery (both are branches of celiac trunk) and superior mesenteric artery.

questions.text: All the following are indicators of Human Development Index (HDI) except?

choices.text: GNI per capita in purchasing power parity (PPP)  in USD

questions.solution:
Indicators used in HDI are life expectancy at birth, literacy and enrolment, and GNI per capita in purchasing power parity (PPP) US$.

HDI dimensions or components are longevity, knowledge and income.

Dimension indices for the indicators are life expectancy index, education index and GNI index (income index).

  • Each dimension index is calculated using the formula: Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value)
  • HDI is the geometric mean of the three indices:
    ILife1/3 x    IEducation1/3    x    IIncome1/3

  • Final HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value
  • HDI can be used to compare living standards in different countries.

India currently ranks 131 (HDI is 0.645) on the 2020 Human developmental Index.

Ref: http://hdr.undp.org/en/countries/profiles/IND

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

questions.text: A group of 20 students in a hostel had fried rice as dinner. 6 hours later, they all experienced severe vomiting. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is bacillus cereus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated fried rice.

Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B.cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type

Incubation period

8-16 hours

1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps

Vomiting, abdominal cramps

The emetic form of B. Cereus is associated with contaminated fried rice; the organism is common in uncooked fried rice and it's heat-resistant spores survive the boiling. If cooked rice is not refrigerated, the spores can germinate and produce toxins.

The mainstay of treatment is adequate hydration.

Other Options:

Option B: Enterotoxigenic E.coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours.

Option C: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

Option D:  Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with an abdominal wall mass, initially a bluish birthmark that gradually enlarged. The child appears developmentally normal. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a mass in the inguinal and hypogastric regions. The overlying skin is reddish-blue, smooth, and non-inflamed. No organomegaly is noted. A mild purpuric rash covers the body. Lab results show hemoglobin at 10.6 gm/dl and platelet count at 90,000/Cmm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an infant presenting with an abdominal wall mass, a distended abdomen with a mass in the inguinal and hypogastric regions and given physical examination and lab findings suggest a diagnosis of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (KMS), also known as Kasabach-Merritt phenomenon, is characterized by an enlarging vascular lesion, profound thrombocytopenia, consumptive coagulopathy, and often a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

KMS is associated with vascular tumors, especially kaposiform Hemangio Endothelioma(KHE) and Tufted Angioma(TA).

The syndrome results in a consumptive coagulopathy from platelet trapping and aggregation within a specific type of hemangioma.The hemangioma is often within the skin but can be present anywhere, including retroperitoneal organs, the mediastinum, the pelvis, visceral organs, or the mesentery.

Patients usually show severe thrombocytopenia, low fibrinogen levels, high fibrin degradation products including D-dimer (due to fibrinolysis), and microangiopathic anemia.

Treatment aims to involute the tumour to prevent significant morbidity or mortality, or in response to a life-threatening event. Surgical excision is curative but most lesions are not amenable to this option.Medical management includes 

  • High dose corticosteroids
  • Propanolol
  • Vincristine
  • Actinomycin
  • Interferon - alpha
  • Radiation

Other options:

Option A: Neuroblastoma- It is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla. They arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumors in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. It can be differentiated from KMS by the absence of thrombocytopenia and normal coagulative state. 

Option B: Pyoderma gangrenosum- Neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders.

Option C: Sweet's syndrome presents as an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis which is characterized by non‐itchy, sometimes tender, erythematous plaques and papules.

  • The plaques are often oedematous and as the process develops they may become studded with pseudovesicles or pseudopustules (no fluid collection present).
  • The lesions in Sweet's Syndrome are most commonly distributed on the arms, upper body, head and neck.
  • An associated fever and peripheral leucocytosis are commonly seen and females are more frequently affected.
  • Histological findings include a dense dermal neutrophilic infiltrate with oedema.

questions.text: A man sustained a blow on the lateral aspect of fibula which is likely to result in all of the following features except ________

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the dorsum of foot
Loss of extension of great toe
Loss of sensation over lateral border of foot

questions.solution:
The patient is likely to have fracture involving the neck of the fibula, which is closely related to the common peroneal nerve.

Loss of sensation over the lateral border of foot is not seen in the injury to common peroneal nerve because this area is innervated by sural nerve which is a branch of tibial nerve.

Common peroneal nerve:

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of foot and to the skin over dorsal area of foot except the first webspace and lateral side of little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles and skin between great and second toes.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck: due to direct injury or indirect twisting injury of the lower limb
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of fibula
  • Postpartum nerve injury include injury to the peroneal nerve and injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

Injury to common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as high stepping gait.
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of foot including the medial side of great toe.

 

Note: Ankle reflex is preserved in common peroneal nerve palsy.

questions.text: A veterinarian develops an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm. Gram staining of the culture is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario is Hide- porter's disease or cutaneous anthrax.

The given image shows the bamboo - stick appearance of B.anthrax on gram staining from cultures.

B.anthrax is a gram positive bacteria surrounded by a polypeptide capsule. The anthrax toxin is a complex of 3 fractions, which as a whole produces local eczema & generalised shock. They are,

  • Protective antigen factor ( PA or Factor II )
  • Edema factor ( OF or Factor I )
  • Lethal factor (LF or Factor III )

Human anthrax presents in one of four ways -

Cutaneous Anthrax(Hide porter’s disease): Presents with Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar referred to as malignant pustule. It usually resolves spontaneously.

Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease):This is a Hemorrhagic pneumonia with a high fatality rate. Hemorrhagic meningitis may occur as a complication.

Intestinal Anthrax: It presents with Hemorrhagic diarrhea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities who eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

Anthrax meningitis: This is a fatal infection which occurs when the organism enters the CNS.

LAB DIAGNOSIS:

  1. MICROSCOPY:

           -M'Fadyean's reaction : stains the capsular material

           -Sudan black B stain: Fat globules may be made out within the bacilli.

           - Smears from cultures : Bamboo- stick appearance    
    2.  CULTURE:

           - On nutrient agar plate : Medusa head appearance     
           - On gelatin stab culture: Inverted fir tree appearance  

           - On solid medium : String of pearls reaction

 

 

Scrub typhus is caused by the bacteria ' Orientia tsutsugamushi '. It is characterised by

  • Fever,
  • Chills,
  • Head ache,
  • Body ache,
  • Rash,
  • Eschar formation

Scrub typhus is spread by the bite of larval mites.

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury on his knee a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick as shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows warty lesions on the knee.The history of thorn prick injury and warty, verrucous growth are suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. It is also known as verrucous dermatitis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection caused by fungi of the genus Fonsecae and Cladophialophora. It is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and shows the presence of fungus as round or irregular, dark-brown, yeast like bodies with septae called dark sclerotic bodies. They are also called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of yeast like sclerotic bodies on KOH mount or by culture on Sabouraud agar.
 
Treatment: Amphotericin B, Itraconazole and Voriconazole can be used. 

The following image shows sclerotic bodies:

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and his Xray of both knees are shown below. Which of the following is deficient in this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is  rickets and deficiency of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol /Calcitriol ( biologically active form of Vit D) is seen in rickets.

The symptoms of craniotabes, rachitic rosary along with the xray finding of  bowing of legs makes Rickets the most likely diagnosis.

 Vitamin D, as either cholecalciferol or ergocalciferol does not have significant biological activity. It is activated as follows:

  • Step 1: Skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light (290nm to 315nm), yielding cholecalciferol.
  • Step 2: Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (the most abundant circulatory form of Vitamin D) by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase.
  • Step 3: Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

Calcitriol acts on the bone, intestine and kidney to maintain calcium and phosphate homeostasis.

Note: if the body does not require vitamin-D, in the kidney, 24-hydroxylase converts vitamin D into 24,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, which is an inactive metabolite.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis.
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification (becomes denser in healing rickets, known as the white line of Frenkel).

questions.text: A 51-year-old female comes to the clinic with a history of insidious onset of decreased vision, eye redness, eye pain, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination demonstrates the presence of Onchocerciasis parasitic infection. What is the treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of onchocerciasis is ivermectin. 

Ivermectin: 6 mg single dose repeated every 6-12 monthly, according to the weight of the patient (150 mcg/kg).

Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were given in the past but have been discontinued due to serious adverse effects.

questions.text: Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram:

choices.text: 1: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, 2:  Potassium sparing diuretics

questions.solution:
1 is the thick descending limb of the loop of Henle and osmotic diuretics act on this part of the nephron.

2 is the collecting ducts and potassium-sparing diuretics act on this part of the nephron.

Site of action of other diuretics:

  • Proximal tubule- carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Ascending limb of the loop of Henle - loop diuretics
  • Distal convoluted tubule - thiazides

The image given below shows the sites of action of diuretics:

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑ No change
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: A female patient visits the OPD with complaints of swelling around her eye as shown in the image. Which of the following transmits the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image above is Romana’s sign. It is seen in acute Chagas disease which is caused by the flagellate Trypanosoma cruzi. It is transmitted by the Reduviid bug.

The person can become infected if T. cruzi parasites in the bug feces enter the body through mucous membranes or breaks in the skin. The sleeping person may accidentally scratch or rub the feces into the bite wound, eyes, or mouth. 

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

The chronic phase is characterized by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This may lead to congestive heart failure presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: A 75-year old male patient was admitted to the clinic with right-sided peripheral facial paralysis that developed 3 days before admission. Patient also complained about painless chronic aural discharge (he had a ten year history of right side otorrhea  that was refractory to medical treatment) and unilateral hearing loss that intensified during time. Clinical examination revealed total perforation of the right tympanic membrane. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is that of Tuberculous otitis media.
Tubercular otitis media does not present with an earache.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis It presents as painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in middle ear cleft are seen.

Pathology: Submucosal tubercles in middle ear cleft, necrosis of tympanic membrane

Complications: Facial nerve palsy (most common), Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis.

Treatment: ATT, aural toilet, treatment of secondary infection, mastoid surgery for complications.

Other bacterial otitis media generally present with painful ear discharge.

Syphilitic otitis media presents with foetid ear discharge due to necrotic bone material.

Fungal otitis media is usually associated with itching and sense of fullness.

questions.text: In rural areas one ASHA worker caters a population of _______.
questions.solution:
The general norm is one ASHA worker for 1000 population.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

 

 Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA)

An ASHA acts as a depot holder for these essential supplies, hence making it readily available to her community. These include Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORS), Iron Folic Acid Tablet (IFA), chloroquine, Disposable Delivery Kits (DDK), Oral Pills & Condoms, etc.

General norm:

  • Must be a woman - married/divorced/widow (age group 25-45 years)
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000.

Relaxations in the general norm:

  • If no candidate is available with a qualification of 10th standard, the requirement can be relaxed to 8th standard.
  • In tribal, hilly and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Note: The States have been given the flexibility to relax the population norms as well as the educational qualifications on a case to case basis, depending on the local conditions as far as her recruitment is concerned. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ER following a road traffic accident. A neurologic exam showed a hyperactive knee jerk reflex and a positive Babinski sign. Which of the following is not a feature of UMN lesion ?
questions.solution:
Hypotonia is seen in an LMN lesion while hypertonia is seen in UMN lesion.

In an upper motor neuron lesion, there is damage to the corticospinal or corticobulbar fibers. If the corticospinal fibers are damaged, it leads to loss of fine skilled movement and spasticity.

Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes, when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of the toes.

 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting . UMN lesions result in weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A medical student  is preparing to do a prospective cohort study for the association of hypertension  with CHD from the general medicine wards. Which of the following must she do?

choices.text: Exclude  all patients diagnosed with hypertension recently
Exclude all the patients on antihypertensive medications
Exclude all the  patients with diagnosis of CHD
Exclude all the patients diagnosed with hypertension more than 3 years back

questions.solution:
Cohort studies progress from cause to effect. Thus, the patients with CHD must be excluded. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

ANALYTICAL EPIDEMIOLOGY

 Analytical studies differ from descriptive studies in that the the subject of interest is the individual within the population whereas in descriptive studies the entire population is studied. 

Analytical studies includes :
      (i) Case control study
      (ii) Cohort study.

By performing an analytical study one can find :
(i) if a statistical association exists between a disease and a suspected factor or not ; and
(ii) if there is one , the strength of the Association.

 Differences between case control and cohort studies:

Case control study Cohort study
1. Proceeds from "effect to cause". Proceeds from "cause to effect"
2. Starts with the disease Starts with people exposed to risk factor or suspected cause.
3. Tests whether the suspected cause occurs more frequently in those with the disease than among those without the disease. Tests whether disease occurs more frequently in those exposed, than in those not similarly exposed.
4. Usually the first approach to the testing or a hypothesis, but also useful for exploratory studies. Reserved for testing of precisely formulated hypothesis.
5. Involves fewer number or subjects Involves larger number of subjects.
6. Yields relatively quick results. Long follow-up period often needed. involving delayed results.
7. Suitable for the study of rare diseases. Inappropriate when the disease or exposure under investigation is rare.
8. Generally yields only estimate of RR (odds ratio). Yields incidence rates, RR as well as AR.
9. Cannot yield information about diseases other than that selected for study. Can yield information about more than one disease outcome.
10. Relatively inexpensive Expensive.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. The opponens pollicis muscle is inserted at this site.

Opponens pollicis:

  • Origin:  Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and the adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
The intrinsic muscles of the hand are organized into three groups plus a superficial muscle.
  • Thenar muscles - Flexor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Adductor pollicis
  • Hypothenar muscles- Abductor digiti minimi, Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Opponens digiti minimi
  • Interossei and lumbricals
  • Palmaris brevis - Superficial muscle that lies beneath the ulnar palmar skin
MUSCLE ORIGIN INSERTION ACTION
Flexor pollicis brevis
Superficial head:
  1. Distal border of the flexor retinaculum
  2. Distal part of the tubercle of the trapezium
Deep head:
  1. Trapezoid
  2. Capitate 
  3. Palmar ligaments of the distal row of carpal bone
  1. Radial side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Flexion of MCP joint
Abductor pollicis brevis
 
  1. Flexor retinaculum
  1. Radial side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
  2. Dorsal digital expansion of the thumb
 Abduction of thumb
Opponens pollicis
  1. Tubercle of the trapezium
  2. Flexor retinaculum
  1. Whole length of the lateral border and the adjoining lateral half of the palmar surface of the metacarpal bone of the thumb
Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb
Palmaris brevis
  1. Flexor retinaculum
  2. Medial border of the central part of the palmar aponeurosis
  1. Dermis on the ulnar border of the hand
  1. Wrinkles the skin on the ulnar side of the palm of the hand and
  2. Deepens the hollow of the palm by accentuating the hypothenar eminence

questions.text: A 53-year-old comes to the clinic with redness, pain, and blurring of vision in the left eye. Patient recently uses contact lens. On examination, there is diffuse redness, a hypopyon on the anterior chamber and decreased visual acuity in the left eye.  Cultures show filamentous fungal keratitis by Fusarium species and patient was started on topical Natamycin. Which of the following would you add to this patient's treatment?
questions.solution:
Natamycin eye drops is the drug of choice for filamentous fungal keratitis.

Oral Ketoconazole or voriconazole helps pts who develop hypopyon/perforated ulcer/suspected endopthalmitis

 

Treatment of fungal corneal ulcer

  • Topical antifungal drops
    • Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B, fluconazole (0.2%) against Aspergillus and Fusarium.
    • Amphotericin B (0.15%) or econazole (1%) against Candida
  • Systemic antifungals: (azoles)
    • Ketoconazole or voriconazole may be required if the ulcers are severely infected with hypopyon or perforated or if endophthalmitis is suspected.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What are the Functional residual capacity and expiratory reserve volume, respectively?
questions.solution:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume

In the given spirogram,

  • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L
  • Residual Volume = 1L

Therefore,

Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2

Note:

The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration.

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration

The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.5 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: Globoid cells in Krabbe disease are________.
questions.solution:
Globoid cells in Krabbe disease are the macrophages.

Krabbe's disease

  • Also called Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Leukodystrophyare disorders caused by mutations of genes whose products are involved in the generation, turnover or maintenance of myelin.
  • Krabbe's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and presence of globoid bodies in white matter 
  • It is a disorder of myelin destruction due to deficiency of galactocerebroside beta-galactosidase, an enzyme required to convert galactocerebroside to ceramic & galactose.
  • As a result, there will be elevated levels of galactosylsphingosine, an alternative pathway product; this is toxic to both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.
  • The disease is rapidly progressive.
  • Brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes; Neurons and axons are relatively spared.
  • A unique and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages (globoid cells) in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.
  • Most patients die by 2 years of age.

questions.text: Lever ratio of the ear ossicles is
questions.solution: Lever action of the ossicles - Handle of malleus is 1.3 times longer than long process of the incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury in the area supplied by the middle cerebral artery. Which of the following functional areas of the brain is least likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Primary visual area is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery and hence is least likely to be affected here.

A vascular injury to the middle cerebral artery affects the lateral area of cortex mainly. All the other options in the question are supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

The blood supply of the brain:

  • Blood is mainly supplied by Internal Carotid artery and vertebrobasilar arteries.
  • Cortical supply is mainly by cortical arteries (Anterior, Middle and Posterior).

Anterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure
  • Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Middle Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure
  • Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Posterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves behind the midbrain
  • Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe
