questions.text: At what age, normal level of visual acuity is attained?
questions.solution:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years.

Important milestones in the visual development are:

  • At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly.
  • By the first month of life, fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months.
  • By 3 months, binocular vision is established.
  • By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed.
  • By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
In the above graph, LD50 = 500, and ED50 = 100; TI = LD50 / ED50

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 500/100 = 5

The Therapeutic Index (TI) (also referred to as therapeutic ratio) is a comparison of the amount of a therapeutic agent that causes the toxicity (e.g. lethal dose in 50% of subjects, LD50) to the amount that causes the therapeutic effect (e.g. efficacious dose in 50% of subjects, ED50).

The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

LD50 (median lethal dose) or TD50 (median toxic dose)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die
  • Larger the LD50 safer the drug
  • In humans, TD50 is considered 
  • TD50: the dose of a drug that causes a toxic response in 50% of the population

ED50 : (median effective dose)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: A 32 year old female who is a  known case of Crohn's disease underwent ileal resection for the presence of stricture. She became a strict vegan post surgery and several months later presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands. Which is the most likely reason for her symptom?
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

In addition to this, a strict vegan diet also leads to vitamin B12 deficiency as meat and dairy products are avoided which are rich sources of vitamin B12.

B12 deficiency :

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin(Vit B12) deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anaemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (subacute combined degeneration). 
  • Psychiatric disturbances

 

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: The arrow marked in the following picture depicts ?
questions.solution:
The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. 

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

  • The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin. 
  • The thick filaments are lined up to form the A bands, whereas the array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.
  • The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments. 
  • The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments.
  • Alpha actinin binds actin to Z lines, titin binds Z lines to myosin, and desmin binds Z lines to plasma membrane.

 

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used as an ammonia scavenger while treating urea cycle disorders?
questions.solution:
Arginine is not used as an ammonia scavenger. It is used as first line treatment in all deficiencies of the urea cycle (except those with arginase deficiency) as it provides ornithine; a positive regulator of urea cycle. Arginine also activates NAG synthase which increases NAG; a positive regulator of urea cycle.

Ammonia Scavengers diverts urea into an alternate pathway and reduces the amount of ammonia.

Drugs that can be used to achieve the same outcome (ammonia scavengers) include:

  • Phenylbutyrate
  • Phenylacetate
  • Benzoate

questions.text: A 60-yr-old man presents with dyspnea and cough. Chest x-ray studies reveal irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient may develop all the following diseases except__________.
questions.solution:
The image shows beaded rods of asbestos bodies (ferruginous bodies) seen in asbestosis. Asbestosis would not lead to laryngeal carcinoma. Lung carcinomas, colon carcinomas and mesotheliomas develop in workers exposed to asbestos.

The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. Asbestos generally occurs in 2 forms - Serpentine chrysotile and Amphibole. Amphiboles, though less prevalent than chrysotiles are more pathogenic and are involved in the occurrence of mesothelioma, a malignant tumour derived from the lining cells of the pleural surfaces.

In contrast to other inorganic dust, asbestos acts as a tumour initiator and a tumour promoter. Some of its oncogenic effects are mediated by reactive free radicals generated by the asbestos fibres.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies. Asbestos bodies are golden-brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent center and consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material and arise when macrophages phagocytose asbestos fibers.

Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.

Asbestosis begins as fibrosis around the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts and most commonly arises in the lower lobe. Pleural plaques are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen that are often calcified and are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure.

Clinical features include,

  • Dyspnoea
  • Productive cough

The chest x-ray shows irregular linear densities in the lower lobes and a honeycomb pattern in advanced cases.

The disease may remain stable or progress to respiratory failure, Cor pulmonale and death.

Asbestos exposure is linked with 6 disease processes:

  • Parenchymal Interstitial Fibrosis ( Asbestosis)
  • Localised pleural plaques or rarely diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusion
  • Lung carcinoma 
  • Malignant pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma 
  • Laryngeal cancer.

Cigarette smoking increases the risk of lung cancer in people with asbestos exposure.

Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dusts (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: A 2 day old male baby is admitted to the NICU due to poor feeding and rapid breathing  since birth. The baby also had one episode of seizure. On blood investigations, there is increased levels of lactate and hyperammonemia. The above condition is caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Congenital Lactic Acidosis which is due to Inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, a defect in any one/ more of the components of the PDH enzyme complex.

This often presents at infancy with lethargy, tachypnea and poor feeding. Other severe symptoms include ataxia, hypotonia and seizures. Blood investigations show a high level of lactate (lactic acidosis) and in some cases hyperammonemia.

Causes of lactic acidosis:

  1. Tissue hypoxia
  2. Mitochondrial disorders
  3. Deficiency of:   
    • PDH Enzyme
    • TCA cycle enzymes
    • Vit B1
  4. Poisoning :     
    • Cyanide 
    • Mercury
    • Arsenite

questions.text: Name the cell which is related to the optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell is related to optic nerve

Onodi cell (sphenoethmoidal cell) is a posterior ethmoidal cell extending into sphenoid sinus. It is surgically important as the optic nerve and internal carotid artery may be related to its lateral wall.

Haller cell is related to maxillary sinus.

 Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus (orbital floor) above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with the history of having have ingested one of the seeds shown in the image below. It causes:
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica. It causes Strychnine poisoning. Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 
The seed yield 2 principal alkaloids :  strychnine and brucine.

Facts about strychnine poisoning:

  • Fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.
  • Fatal period is usually few hours.

  • If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature - postmortem caloricity.

  • The toxin Strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

TREATMENT:

  1. Patient is kept in a dark, noiseless room so as to minimise stimulation.
  2. Convulsions may be controlled by diazepam 0.1-0.5mg/kg IV slowly and then phenobarbital IV. If these drugs prove ineffective, consider general anaesthesia/ muscle relaxants.
  3. Short acting barbiturates like phenobarbital sodium or sodium Amytal are antidotes to strychnine and should be given in a dose of 0.3- 0.6 gm IV.
  4. Stomach wash with warm water and dilute solution of potassium permanganate/ tannic acid.
  5. Gastric lavage with activated charcoal.
  6. Acidification of urine will increase excretion of strychnine.
  7. Tracheostomy with oxygen supply may be necessary.

POST-MORTEM APPEARANCE:

  • They are similar to that of asphyxia.
  • The remains of the seed may be found in stomach.
  • Brain and spinal cord need to be preserved in addition to the viscera and blood, in case of strychnine poisoning.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

  • Mnemonic to remember signs and symptoms.
  • We know that CRAMPing of muscles leads to the exhaustive death of the person in strychnine poisoning. Therefore:
    • Convulsions
    • Reflex increased
    • Awful taste
    • Mind is conscious
    • Pupils dilated
  • Clonic-tonic convulsions
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus: fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Medico-legal implications:.

  • Although a poison, in relatively low doses can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: The phases of  ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image,  fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open?
questions.solution:
The fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open in the phase 2 of the action potential producing the plateau in the graph.

Phases of cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and causes sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 
  • Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phase 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the a decrease in efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  approximately -90 millivolts.

questions.text: A 27-year-old known asthmatic comes to the ER with shortness of breath. On auscultation, Bilateral expiratory wheeze is heard. On examination, blood pressure was - 110/70 mmHG, and the respiratory rate was 25 breaths/min. Patient was started on inhalational corticosteroids and bronchodilators. How does corticosteroid act to improve the patient's condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthines on adenosine receptor

questions.solution:
Corticosteroids improved the condition by decreasing the mucous secretion.

Mechanism of action of Corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to Beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta 2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: A 50 year old man got stuck inside a building on fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning and the cause of death in this patient with carbon monoxide poisoning is anemic hypoxia.

CARBON MONOXIDE POISONING: 
Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to hemoglobin compared to oxygen and forms a stable compound known as 'carboxyhemoglobin' (COHb) and hence the amount of hemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced, thus producing ' anemic hypoxia'.

An additive factor influencing the toxicity of CO is the fact that the presence of COHb shifts the oxygen-  hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left, thereby increasing the bondage of Hb with oxygen and reducing its release to the tissues. 

It is important to note that in the case of anemic hypoxia, O2 content is low but dissolved O2 is within normal limits so it does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

Poisoning by CO is mostly accidental. The decrepit, the diseased, the drugged and the drunk are more often involved in accidental poisoning.

The human fetus is particularly sensitive to CO because,

  1. Greater concentrations of Hb leading to greater  COHb in the fetus rather than in the mother.
  2. Partial pressure of oxygen in the fetal blood is lower than the adults.
  3. The fetal oxygen - hemoglobin dissociation curve lies to the left of the adult curve, leading to greater tissue hypoxia at equivalent COHb concentrations.

Patients recovering from CO poisoning may suffer neurological sequelae including

  • Tremors 
  • Personality changes 
  • Memory impairment 
  • Monoplegia 
  • Hemiplegia 
  • Psychosis 
  • Peripheral neuropathy 
  • Visual loss 
  • Inability to concentrate and 
  • Parkinsonism within 2-4 weeks.

Symptoms of chronic poisoning of CO include: 

  • Head ache 
  • Confusion 
  • Weakness 
  • Paresthesias 
  • Hypertension 
  • Hyperthermia 
  • Visual disturbances 
  • Palpitations 
  • Atrial fibrillation 
  • AV block 
  • Decreased cognitive ability 
  • Parkinsonism, etc.,

TREATMENT:

  1. Remove the patient to fresh air immediately. If he is conscious and breathing, no treatment is required.
  2. Any patient with COHb levels greater than 25% should be treated. 
  3. Provide 100% oxygen with a tight fitting mask.
  4. CO2 should not be given.
  5. Gastric lavage.
  6. Whole blood transfusion.
  7. Mannitol, steroids and fluid restriction to treat cerebral edema.
  8. Prophylactic antibiotics
  9. Complete rest for 48 hours.
  10. Avoid stimulant drugs.

POST-MORTEM APPEARANCE:

Typical ' cherry red' discolouration of skin and mucous membrane is seen.

Note: Carbon monoxide poisoning causes both anemic (due to CO-Hb) and histotoxic (due to inhibition of cyt c oxidase) hypoxia. But the main cause of death is due to anemic hypoxia.

questions.text: Which Vitamin forms a part of Coenzyme A and acyl carrier protein (ACP)?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic Acid (Vitamin B5) acts as the pantetheine functional moiety in Coenzyme A and acyl carrier protein (ACP)

Vitamin B5 plays a central role in acyl group metabolism.

Functions of CoA (Coenzyme A) :

Takes part in the reactions of 

  • Citric acid cycle
  • Fatty acid oxidation
  • Acetylations
  • Cholesterol synthesis

ACP plays a major role in Fatty Acid synthesis

Other options :

Option A: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is responsible for the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and Flavin-adenine-dinucelotide (FAD)

Option B: Niacin (Vitamin B3) helps in the formation of coenzymes Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and NADP

Option D: Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) forms Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding?
questions.solution:
Image "D" is the answer.

The given endoscopic image depicts an esophageal exophytic growth in the middle-third of the esophagus.

Barium swallow shows the “apple core appearance” of an esophageal lesion in the middle-third, which is suggestive of esophageal carcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common cancer of esophagus worldwide. It is most frequently is found in the mid-esophagus, where it commonly causes strictures.

Risk factors include 

  • Alcohol & tobacco use
  • Poverty
  • Caustic esophageal injury 
  • Achalasia
  • Plummer- Vinson syndrome 
  • Radiation, etc.,

Presenting symptoms may be, 

  • Dysphagia
  • Odynophagia
  • Progressive esophageal obstruction 
  • Weight loss & debilitation
  • Iron deficiency anemia, etc.,

Early lesions appear as small, gray-white, plaque-like thickenings. Over years, they grow into tumour masses that may be polyploid or exophytic and protrude into and obstruct the lumen. Infiltrative tumours can cause esophageal wall thickening, rigidity and luminal narrowing. Tumours may invade the surrounding structures such as, 

  •           The respiratory tree - causing pneumonia   
  •           The aorta - causing catastrophic exsanguination
  •           The mediastinum 
  •           The pericardium

 Most SCCs are moderate to well differentiated. The rich lymphatic network of esophagus promotes metastases as well as longitudinal & circumferential spread. The sites of lymph node metastases vary with the tumour location:

  •     Upper third - Cervical lymph nodes
  •     Middle third - Mediastinal, Paratracheal & Tracheobronchial nodes
  •     Lower third - Gastric & Celiac nodes.

Prognosis is poor with lymph node metastases.

Squamous cell carcinoma composed of nests of malignant cells that partially recapitulate the stratified organization of squamous epithelium.

Among the given images, "D" shows the correct histopathological picture of squamous cell carcinoma.

Other options:

A: Normal esophageal mucosa

B: Barret esophagus

C: Adenocarcinoma esophagus
